description:
Pliny The Elder.  On Tap.

Not sure if this is a usual occurrence, but it is enough for me to want to check this place out every single time I go here!  Which isn't very frequently, but it's about to be a whole lot more frequently if this is the case!

If you are not familiar with Pliny (Elder/Younger), then I strongly suggest you get off your butt, climb outta your shell, and go familiarize yourself!  It's super good, DIPA, Strong, but goes down oh so easily.  I was blown away by the fact it was on tap.  Almost didn't want to leave, but adventures must be had, and they only go so far when you're in a bar all day.

Anyway, staff was super friendly and chill.  Y'all should come check it out because, ya know, stuff.

KThxBai! LUVYOU!!!
author: Michael S.

description:
As a devout fan of futbal once every four years, it was imperative for me to find a bar that allowed me to showcase my passionate fandom in between bouts of affordable beer. Luckily, I found Murio's. And in this fine establishment, my World Cup experience this past month was everything I had imagined.

Murio's has three large televisions. Two of them were along the bar, one on each side. Great for if you have a seat along the bar as you can chat up the barkeep about the current state of modern football -- that is when she isn't super busy dealing out $5 Modelo's. The largest TV is off to the side, for the viewing pleasure of the lounge area. This area is furnished with large L-shaped couches, ideal for group sizes between 4 to 10. When occupied, it gives that fervent energy one looks for in a sports bar, combined with the rare comfort of personal space commonly forgone during a sporting event.

The bar was a little too intimidating for me. I feel like if your Manchester United jersey is not advertising vodafone, you may not be ready to appreciate the subtle intricacies in the "pitch" as many of the bar side stalwarts would. I'm sure they're all still very inclusive, I just don't wanna answer with "FIFA" to when they drop that friendly - "I'm a left wing back. Whaddaya play, mate?"

My buddy and I spent most of my 90 minutes plus stoppage time in the lounge area, enjoying the World Cup in the only way we know how --- directing troll comments at the world class athletes as they flash across the screen.

"Damn does Toni Kroos spend his offseason at Vegas DJ-ing?"

"Yo the Croatia jersey reminds me of the checkered wax paper from Golden Boy's Pizza"

The more beer, the less tact.

"Breh Modric looks like Steve Nash without sunlight."

"Oh wait watch-- wait-- ah damn! I thought Suarez was gonna bite him from the back right there!"

"Let God save the Queen, Pickford you save that goal"

There will be a point in alcohol consumption when the indecencies from our mouths are assuaged, if only by its incoherency. Instead of becoming a nuisance, our recent loss of intelligible speech becomes a welcomed excitement added to the bar. We begin to exchange high fives with new found friends.

"ALL ABOARD THE LUKAKU TRAIN!"

"It's ha-mays. HA-mays. HA-MAYS Rodriguez."

"MBAPPPPPPE!!! That boiiiiii fast"

"RaHEEEEEEEMMM"

Jubilation in the air, beer dripping freely from our chin, and flashes of thumbs up to the bartender who still manages to find time to clear empty glasses from our den. It did not matter if a jersey had three lions, or if they looked like pizza wax paper. Everyone was just at Murio's to have a good time, and a good time was there to be had.

It only happens once every four years. Thanks Murio's for making it count.
author: Ringo M.

description:
Always great music that I actually wanna listen to!! But I will also preface this with I'm a Goth/alternative/rocker type chick so I like listening to rock/alternative at bars that I can't find often. 

Just went here on a Monday for a first date and had an absolute blast!! 

Because it was a weeknight it was pretty dead which meant no one fighting over the pool table! I had forgotten how much I love playing pool even if I'm not that great I still have a really fun time playing. Time to save up my quarters!! The tables a dollar a game. 

Officially my fav bar on Upper Haight!!
author: Goth Kitty Jen J.

description: Local low key chill spot. Because it's pretty much locals. Had 2 grey goose something's and a bag of chips for $22. I was like whaaaaa? And the bar is fully stocked with a bunch of good shit. Wide range. PBR, local stuff like Junipero and something called Writer's Tears which is intriguing. Makes me want to be a writer so I can legit drink it and maybe cry after ?
author: JoJo W.

description: Decent enough bar and an easy place to get pliny, which may no longer retain it's lofty status given the bevy of excellent beer that has flourished in the last few years, but is still pretty damned good.
author: Misha T.

description: Very friendly, chill spot. ~6 beers on tap, definitely not a craft beer bar (which keeps it from being stuffy and pricey!), with a standard cocktail menu. Excellent spot to stop in and grab a casual drink and people / mural watch out the window.
author: Steven E.

description:
Went to Haight Street to check out record stores and stroll.  After an hour I needed a bathroom and a cocktail. Murio's was close by.  They had some drink specials visible from the outside that sounded good.  
We ended up ordering a gin and tonic, and a moscow mule.  Standard drink, nothing special.  Bathroom was available-little hole in the wall across from the bar.  Looks like there was more comfy seating towards the back of the bar past the pool table.  It felt like a neighborhood bar, it was mid afternoon and there were already a couple of groups that were feeling good.  Bar tender was nice and moved quickly.  Drinks were moderately priced. After our drinks we decided to move on to another spot.
author: Amanda F.

description:
This bar was aight. The drinks were meh, the music was old school nothing familiar. 

Not sure if it was because we were there on a Saturday afternoon. We played pool, which was missing one of the striped balls. We noticed a second set after a few games and played another round. 

We had a few vodka sodas and some super cheap champagne.. it was Andres or something like that.
author: Nicole G.

description:
Criminal.

Tired, I stopped in for a nightcap after a long night of work. 

Set my glasses on the table to look at my phone.

The bartender came over suddenly and wiped off the table. I didn't think anything of it, lifting my beer. 

When I got up to leave, I could not find my glasses. 

Yep, you guessed it, the shady bartender swiped them!

Unbelievable. Really. F#$% this place and that beardo bartender.
author: Chris M.

description:
Worst bartender I've ever met. Incredibly rude. Slow service. Doesn't care about customers. I ordered one beer and he acts like I'm asking for some ridiculous mixed drink then calls me an "amateur".  Do not drink here.
.
author: Jason D.

description: This super stylish space next to Parada 22. This sweet neighborhood, ahhh! The lighting, the company, the mixologists, the jukebox....It's my favorite place to go for happy hour, especially when Rob is working.
author: Helen K.

description:
This place is a joke. I'm always down to give spots more than one try before I write a review. Came on a Saturday after the sf deltas soccer game and it was kind of packed. I was surprised to see one bartender. He was super slow and rude. The bar back was clearly drunk, he wasn't cleaning any of the glasses people dropped on the floor. I was DD this night so all I wanted was sprite, when my bf ordered their cocktails he asked for a sprite next and the bartender said some sarcastic joke that rubbed me the wrong way. Am I not allowed to have soda? 

Came again on a Saturday and it was pretty dead. Yet it still felt like a hassle to get a drink from the same bartender. We learned to order doubles because it's nearly impossible to wave him down for another round whether it was busy or not. 

Overall the place is an upgrade from what it used to look like. 
There's a pool table, so bring your quarters.
Lots of bar seating and table seats in the front and back!
author: Brittany C.

description: Strong drinks and a inappropriate bouncer at the door. Lots of seating, nice interior, plenty of space to move around.
author: Daryll G.

description: I like this place, mainly because they have Russian River beer on tap and it's a good spot for people watching on Haight Street. The Sunday afternoon lady (short, dark hair) was drinking a lot, pretty drunk and only paid attention to her friends (who were wasted and loud). Other than that, no frills place for great beer.
author: Lia B.

description:
So I'm a regular at the hookah bar next door. The first time I ever came here was last Friday, because my friend from the hookah lounge, wanted to buy me a birthday shot. Friday was awesome, bar tender was sweet and gave me/us no hassle (bigger husky guy), wait was only 5mins if that. I'd have given them more stars ONLY IF my second day went better....

Ended back up here the very next day, as its conveniently located immediately next to the hookah lounge. This time I had a HORRIBLE experience for my second birthday drink....

Saturday there was an asian guy bartender, after waiting 20 mins for him to get back to our end of the bar, I asked for a lemon drop...he first started flipping through a book (which we're assuming was a book on how to make the lemon drop, he started walking up and down the bar looking for something). Then came back and asked again if I was ready, and I again asked for a lemon drop, he asked me what? what? like he couldn't hear me, then asked me what is a lemon drop, whats in it.......my three friends and I were shocked and appalled by this statement from a BAR TENDER!!. He started being VERY MEAN and angry, and then started saying he has too many patrons etc etc to be making difficult drinks...um what?  you just spent more than 5 mins walking up and down the bar flipping through a book, and its like three liquid ingredients and ice...

I SHOULD have just listened to my friend and gone to Cha Cha Cha on the corner, too bad I rejected saying I came here just the day before.... WILL NOT BE RETURNING, will walk just 10 more steps and go to Cha Cha Cha or Milk Bar (when they don't have a line!).
author: Nais K.

description: Worst service I've ever had in my life!!! Guy, spiked hair! We bought one drink and tried to pay with a credit card and was soooooo mean... we had already bought 4 drinks with a good tip.. then bought one and he wouldn't except our card... never told us there was a $15 minimum.. if so we would have got cash or gaven him it but instead tried to start a fight.. just moved down the street and will NEVER come back!! Disappointed
author: Sarah G.

description: We just walked into this bar and the bartender accused us of having fake IDs without checking them electronically. He hit on my friend sexually and made them uncomfortable so they walked out. He insisted they return and made them pay for the drink he initially denied them. "Worst. Service. Ever." - The Comic Book Guy from The Simpsons.
author: Samantha S.

description: Yo! This place is theeeee shiiiiiit. Robert straight killed it while serving up some bad ass grape kool aid. Fun crowd, good music, what the fuck else do you want?
author: David R.

description: Great place to have a drink, bartenders are awesome and super friendly! Its a must go!
author: KillJoii X.

description: I went here on a Thursday night and the bartender was rude as hell. I would not recommend
author: Briana M.

description: Great local boozer. Had a few pints in here after walking Golden Gate Park and the bridge. The patrons and barmaid gave me plenty of good advice for stuff in the area to do.
author: Robert O.

description:
#133
Yaya for Murio's Trophy Room!

I was in the Haight area with my favorite bar crawl friend David and we stopped in to the Trophy Room for a cocktail as the street festival was happening.  We wanted to try as many bars on the street as we could while we meandered our way down the block for street food and cool vendor items.  

David and I walked in to Murio's and all of a sudden the bartender yells out, "What's up mutha-fucas!?!?!?"  Well, that is one of the best greetings I have obtained in a long time, so I am down to stay and drink with this guy.

i greeted this loud individual and I asked his name.  "Danny, what the hell do you want?"  If I were not already spoken for, I'm telling you--charmer... LMFAO!

Anyway... Danny made us two fabulous cocktails, I mean FABULOUS!  I had a martini and David had a Corona.  We wanted to play pool as we saw the tables and grabbed a few quarters and our drinks and made our way to the back of the bar.

We chose from the plethora of warped sticks hanging on the wall, put our quarters in the table and it was time to beat my BFF down on the billiard table.  We played a game or two and another challenger came along.  No problem.  I had it--won our table back, grabbed a couple more cocktails and then we thought we would meander outside back to the street fair.  I mean, that is what we came for, we just got a little sidetracked--as always ;)

Danny was one of the most personable bartenders I have ever had the pleasure of meeting.  He makes a mean drink and has nothing but funny things to say.  Now, that is a bartender--and Murio's is a cool bar.

Stephani Smiles for Murio's Trophy Room ;)
author: Stephani M.

description: I feel bad giving a bad review,  for the bartenders that work there, but this is about the door man today 06/16/2018, 1:15 AM. I've been going to Murio's for about 7 years. I work at the food industry as well. The way I was treated last night was not right. I was waiting outside for my Uber that was 5 min away and door man said I had to leave and I couldn't wait outside of the bar, being really rude for no reason. What??? Are you serious? It's not like a nightclub with a line blocking the sidewalk!! I'm a woman outside of the bar I just left,  waiting for my ride home!! And I work at the closest bar two blocks away and I know a few of your bartenders for years. What was this about? I really like a couple of the bartenders there, but that just did it for me. I was literally standing outside of the bar waiting for my Uber, is that ilegal? Used to like this place, not going back. Hire professional and decent people for the door!
author: Lovinglife P.

description: Love this place! You can play pool, get an Irish coffee made with a french press AND it's dog friendly!
author: Dinah M.

description: Robert the Sweet guy with the rocky cigar shirt is the friggin awesome and hustles like a mofo! First time at the bar and being a CEO of a growing biz I would put him in management if I could. You don't see this everrrrrrrr!
author: Sienna G.

description: Perfect place to walk in a have a beer ! The Prices are good with $8 shots. Good to go to after a nice shopping spree at Haight St. All the bartenders are ready to serve !
author: Charlie S.

description:
This bar is fine, but the bartender is a mean-spirited fellow. He was an a-hole to me and my 3 friends without any provocation. It's a bummer that this guy feels he needs to put down his bar patrons to feel like work is worth going to. 

Most bartenders are hired for their friendly, sociable demeanor (and drink-making talent). Don't know what the Murio's management team has in mind, letting this dude interact with customers. He's rude and sloppy. 

As far as I gathered, one of the things he yelled at us about was ordering soda, bitters & lime. It's pretty poor taste for a bartender to talk down to someone for drinking soda. We also each got greyhounds -- which is beside the point.

Perhaps if your shtick is to make fun of patrons and it's actually funny or in the spirit of a good time in any way... That could maybe fly... But just yelling at whoever orders a drink and calling them names? Who wants to party with a dude like that? 

I hope you find peace, angry Murio's bartender dude. I pity you.
author: Yak T.

description: Came here on a Monday night after a great comedy show at Milk Bar. We sat by the "fire" and had a few rounds of drinks already (which weren't great), when I went up to the bar to grab a few waters for the table (gotta keep hydrated). I had a few bucks to tip for the water in my hand, very visible. I gladly waited my turn to be helped, was very patient, and when the bartender, Robert, approached me I asked for two waters. His response? "Oh for fucks sale." I was completely appalled by that response, he sounded so angry that I ordered the waters, slammed them onto the table and said nothing to me. I thanked him, despite the rude exchange, and went back to the table. My friends and I will not be coming back to this bar after that awful remark.
author: Leilani V.

description: My favorite bar on Haight Street. Love that they serve Pliny the Elder, play great music, and have a pool table. A more relaxed spot though so not great for groups
author: Hunter R.

description: This is a great locals place in the middle of a tourist ridden area. Fresh greyhounds are a nice surprise given the beautifully divey(but light) atmosphere. Service is friendly and it's not crowded on a Saturday afternoon. Great post-brunch spot where you can transition from Bloodys to Hounds.
author: Sydney S.

description: A chill neighborhood dive that gets a little cray whenever something is pappin in the Haight. 7$ fresh squeezed greyhounds made with Svedka. Nice bar tenders. Plus, excellent Haight St. people watching through the open windows at the front of the bar. Never a dull moment up here.
author: John D.

description:
What I love about Murio's:
- friendly bar staff (especially Robert - gets me my drink quickly and is always super nice!)
- great prices, tasty Bloody Mary's
- they have Blind Pig on tap (usually)
- pool table!
author: Nancy C.

description:
Came here for the second time last Saturday. It was pretty late, around 12:30am, and went to the bar to order a drink. My friend was going to get the beet and shot combo and give me the shot. I don't think the bartender understood what we were trying to do. He basically yelled at me to pick something, rushing me, because more people were walking in and I assume he wanted to serve them asap. 
He said I could order any well shot I wanted so I asked for Stoli. He condecendingly told me that wasn't well and it isn't well at any bar and told me to pick something else. He stressed me out so much I just wanted to leave. 
Don't tell and condescend to your customers. I just wanted a drink, but instead I ended up feeling shitty because of the bartenders bad attitude. It's still a nice, chill bar...EXCEPT for the service.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Super relaxed, casual bar in Haight Ashbury. We stopped in because they had Pliny on tap.. a highly sought after and super rare beer (especially in the Midwest). The bartender was super friendly, and was busting her booty to keep everyone served and the bar restocked. She definitely took pride in the job! My guy got his Pliny and I got a mixed drink which was $13 in total. It was our cheapest drinks for the whole trip! Bathrooms were clean. I would definitely frequent here if I lived in the area!
author: Suzanne B.

description: The bartender is an ass and a joke.  He has no customer service at all.  We had a group of several people last night and it wasn't that busy but he sure made it seem that our business was such a hassle for him. He was so bugged out that we had credit cards. It's not a cash only bar. I asked for an extra lime and he says "it's always something" in the most sarcastic tone ever.  Then I ordered 5 shots and one of the glasses he was going to pour into was dirty so I asked for anther glass. He already made enough for the five shots but poured it all into the four. Made another round for one more shot and then tried to charge me an extra $10. Wha?? But you just made enough so all you had to do was grab an extra clean glass bruh. If I was the owner of that place, I would be totally embarrassed.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Unpretentious bar with Pliny on tap and freshly squeezed grapefruit juice in your Sculpin. Amazing
author: Ben H.

description: This is the coolest spot, not very big but has a lot of charm. Pool table, cute back lounge with couches and nice lighting, and a bar in front with a good assortment of drinks. Keith and Robert (Batman and Robin) are the coolest bartenders you'll ever meet!!! Will definitely be hitting this spot up whenever I'm on a night out in the city!
author: Kellie S.

description:
I thoroughly loved this place before it remodeled and became awful.

The bartender who looks like a hairier/larger Joey Fatone is a jerk. He seems to make up prices as he goes. Every goddamn beers that he sets down on the bar sloshes out. Idiot.

It's way too loud inside (so is Hobson's, but I forgive them because of most of their other redeeming qualities) and the clientele here seems to be people leaving the methodone clinic or coming on down from Hippie Hill. I'm no snob ... This is my neighborhood ... But this place just has a weird vibe. 

It used to be a fun dive bar, but now it's ewwww.
author: Whitney M.

description: Robert the bartender rocks. Felt warmly welcomed into the bar. Great Happy Hour and a friendly atmosphere on Haight street.  My husband Frank and I  wish we had more time to spend there. We will be back on our next trip to San Francisco.
author: Jill S.

description: I was here a few hours ago and I'm giving 5 stars to the bartender that took the time to make me an amazing Negroni. I only had one and decide to order a beer after I had finished it. Her selection of music was also very good. A nice bar with some chill patrons.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Situation
- Weekday evening drinks with friends

Pros
- Modern Decor
- Good Bartenders
- Great beers on tap

Overall
If I'm in the area, I will definitely try to stop by
author: Dipesh G.

description: Stopped in here to grab a quick drink on a Saturday afternoon. Plenty of tables. Cool location.
author: Nicole D.

description:
My friends and I settled in here over the weekend almost by accident... There was a big pay-per-view fight going on, and we didn't want to pay a cover charge. We arrived fairly early, around 9:00, and the place was mellow when we arrived but hopping by the time we left.

And we were not disappointed. The clientele where fun and in the Christmas spirit, the bartender was a magician, and the drinks were fairly priced. I'd go back in a heartbeat!

...plus, they serve Pliny. Wins on all accounts.
author: Katie P.

description:
The drinks are okay and prices are high, but not unreasonable. Service is average to mediocre. The doorman needs to be replaced. Got the first drink okay, but the second drink... The bartender got chatty with some folks, so after a few minutes waiting and a few more moments of waving my hands around in a fairly empty bar, I stood up on the footrest of a barstool. The bartender noticed quickly, smiled, and started walking over to take my order. None of this bugged me much, it is a bar. Bartenders working by their lonesome don't have eyes in the back of their head. Sometimes you need to get up and wave. I'm not new to how a bar works.

But then, from behind!

A doorman in a leather Crocodile Dundee hat came shuffling up and squawked, "Don't stand on the barstools!" Like he thought I was about to jump on one and start dancing. I wasn't on the barstool, but had my hand resting on the seat and my foot on the footrest to lift myself up as I if I was getting on the stool to sit down. After one drink, I wasn't dunk, and though I was feeling a little impatient, I wasn't doing more than what I do when I get on a stool for any other reason. 

The doorman got a little closer than I generally expect unless someone is trying to get aggressive about something, he shouted like he thought I was deaf, and got in my face, refusing to back off. Basically, agitated bully behavior. So I turned my back on him, announced to my friends we were leaving, and we all walked out. I was the one that invited them there in the first place. I bought a replacement drink at the next bar for the one friend who had not yet finished his, but my other friend and I had been waiting with already empty drinks for the bartender's attention.

I can understand why you might want a doorman who doesn't mind getting in a fight, but one who walks into the bar after a guy and makes up excuses to harass customers is not a wise choice. After going here for six months, never again. Crocodile Dundee, you are a shameful excuse for a doorman. That treatment was offensive. 

Murio's, if you do take action about this incident, write me a response on here so I know to update the review. I'll never go to the bar again, though.
author: Christopher L.

description: Whoever was the bar tender tonight was a total jerk. We walked in at 1:10 (they close at 2), purchased 2 beers and 5 minutes later he started kicking everyone out, saying he was closing the bar. We asked if we could finish our beers and he said no, even though we were halfway done. We mentioned they don't close until 2 and he got angry at us for pointing that out saying "you're really gonna act like this?" Everyone in the bar was confused as to why we were being kicked out. The bar tender ended up giving us our money back so we would leave!!! We essentially got free beers, which was a win for us, but the guy was a total jerk.
author: Angela B.

description:
Sadly, Not a happy camper. I give it the credit that it's an eye pleasing spot with a pool table and mod print wallpaper; better than what I expected from the exterior for ambience, however, service.... Below sub par.

The place wasn't even packed and I waited 5 mins to be served only to be over charged for my drinks - on the chalk board outside listed Pliny was $7 - I got two, and my friend for a grapefruit vodka, which was $7... So doing the math (7x3= $21) so why was my bill $30?!?!? 

To top that off, I asked my friend as he was ordering drinks to get me a glass of water. He ordered drinks too.. But no, this red head bartender dared to be so extremely rude to say "water? That's it.. Water" (... He just ordered 3 drinks from you BTW) and that wasn't the last, she then continued to say "well, you better babysit this because I ain't filling another glass" ... 

If you are too good to serve a glass of water along with cocktails, then have a self serve area for water. What if the person dehydrated, what if that person was a drunk and needed to sober up. Completely unnecessary rudeness and poor service, that we decided to just finish our drinks and leave.
author: Tiffany N.

description: Bartender was an asshole. Whole place smelled kinda gross. I did like that it had a coin-op pool table and ample seating. Will not return as long as that asshole bartender is there. Otherwise just a normal bar.
author: Erika S.

description: Crooks here! Be very careful of this place if visiting from out of town. I was there March 19th in the evening for a few drinks before dinner. The scum bag bartender decided to give himself a $10 tip on my card. Luckily, my cc warned me of this and even luckier, I had the receipt from that night to verify that this bartender was committing fraud. Needless to say that on my next visit to SF, I will NOT be going to this dump for libations.
author: AJ D.

description: came to sf for the weekend.. bar was packed.. robert was legit the hardest working bartender i've ever seen in my life. kudos to robert!! legit made the experience great at murio's!! highly recommend this bar!!
author: Keith B.

description:
Murio's has become one of our favorite bars in the Haight. It has a cozy vibe, complete with comfy chairs and a fireplace.  There is a long bar with stools and a lounge area in the back with low tables and couches. Just as a heads up, there is only one table to roll under.  This used to be a super divey bar, but you would never know it. It's one of the most accessible bars in the whole neighborhood. The front door even has automatic pushbuttons at waist level and foot level. The bathroom is humongous, and well decorated! Even the soap is within reach from a wheelchair, which is saying a lot believe me.  It has a lever doorknob and a perfectly inclusive mirror that's at the right height for almost everyone. 

Although they spruced up the place, they kept the prices at a divey level.  It won't break the bank to hang out for a few hours. As if this wasn't enough, there is even a pool table!
author: Shannon M.

description:
After a shitty experience at CHA CHA CHA, we found this place.

We were super impressed. I had a group of 6, and we were greeted by the very friendly female bartender. This place had great prices, a great bar, cool, eclectic lighting, lots of seating and pool tables in the back. Very chill experience, will be back!
author: Amanda C.

description: We stopped in for a beer and a piss. It's a good Ol dive bar. The bartender was from Ireland, and as expected, she was very sweet. That's about all I have to say. Thanks for the beer.
author: Tony F.

description:
Good drinks.  Sazerac = epic WIN!! I don't even like whiskey much... this is so hard to put down (on the table!) 

Good space.   Dim lighting, but plenty of seating in the back.  There's a pool table here, granted, I didn't enjoy seeing plumber's crack... I think men are going commando these days?!?! 

Prices = reasonable.
author: Fannie S.

description:
We stop there 3 pm wednesday novembre. 3 peoples + us.
Its was a really cool place, big windows. 
I was looking for a place like this during mu trip, I found !
author: Vincent B.

description:
This place has some memories for me. 

I remember it when I first moved to the city. It's a place I'd find myself wandering into while waiting to meet friends. It was an always a dimly lit room full of an interesting mixture of locals and pure randomness. It was never really my kind of spot - but it had a unique charm about it - that always felt familiar and well - alright.

Today I walked past Murio's and didn't even recognize it. It's a whole new place. Same location- but just with a face-lift. They've brightened it up by opening it up with windows. The juke box grins at you. There's a great lounge area to sit down. There's a pool table.  It's comfortable. The bartender is warm and welcoming. Everyone's smiling and just happy to be there. The place  - though much different from it's predecessor  - still feels familiar and well  - alright.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description: Great little bar with a great ambiance. The location (on Haight) is very cool and convenient to get to. The bar itself is very laid back and nice. There's a bar in the front, fake fireplace in the back, and a pool table. The drinks were good, it wasn't too crowded, and the people were nice.
author: Zach H.

description:
Most of these recent reviews are clearly written by people who haven't been to Murio's for like a year and a half.

Murio's is no longer the fun, almost spooky dive bar you are writing about.

In fact, there is nothing divey about the new Murio's.

Right as you cross the threshold of Murio's you feel like you're in an upscale douchebag bar in Cow Hollow. It is depressing.

Murio's WAS an awesome dive bar. It was almost cave-like and scary. I'd watch tourist stroll in and promptly shuffle out with horrified looks. 

I'm not saying they fucked up by changing or anything, I just want people to know this is no longer the super divey local bar everybody keeps writing about.

Decent beer selection, Blind Pig on tap, which rules, lots of liquor, comfy couches in the back, etc.
author: Blake C.

description: Fun place to meet new people and have a drink
author: Mari G.

description: Favorite place in the neighborhood for great pint with window seats to the Haight. Great bar tenders taboot!
author: Matthew T.

description:
This is my favorite bar in The Haight and I will tell you why.

I discoverd Murio's long ago.  It was dark and trashy. And cheap and usually a cast of characters in the afternoon hours who just wanted to get drunk on the cheap.

The new Murio's speaks of what SF is becoming: shiny and lounge like with cool lighting and nice, professional barkeep, I dig it. 

What I really like is this now seems an oasis from the craziness on the street.  Back in the day anyone would wander in here, which I was fine with...but if I worked here I would have grown tired of dealing with that.  Now I feel like this polished, newer version of its previous incarnation is exactly what the neighborhood needed.  I am sure the owner is happier now too as prices have climbed and are more inline with shiny, new bars.

Check it out.  Check out the groovy wallpaper and the awesome pool table.
author: James S.

description: I went to this bar with friends three days ago, and it's the worst experience ever. The bartender was so wasted, they had their last call around 11pm. We had fives drinks and she tried to charge me $82 for it. After communicating for a long time they gave me a fifty something dollars bill to sign, I signed it so I could have my card back and we left. Yesterday I checked my account transition history a $86 bill from this bar went through. I tried to call the place to talk to the manager, nobody ever picked up the phone. It's really not about the money, but my experience with this place is so ridiculous I can't believe it.
author: Kenzo L.

description: Stopped  by here durring happy hour.  It was kind of chilly out and they had Hot Toddys on the happy hour menu.  They were rpetty good and the place is kind of divey though and I got a little bit annoyed by the fruit flies.  Other than that the service was great and the bartender was really friendly.  As far as bars go, I'd have to rate this place right in the middle.
author: Zorin D.

description: Love the staff, great place for a beer and they really give back to community. I used to live around the corner and would come here for live music
author: Chris K.

description:
Every time I wander into Murio's, something inexplicable happens. It's always the last place I end up on my way home, which is trouble enough. I've been known to shoot pool there after dousing myself in a vat of sangria at Cha Cha Cha, or strolling in for a nightcap after giggling uncontrollably over pizza at Escape From New York. Regardless of the million permutations that determine how exactly I end up there (or who I drag with me), it's this kind of safe-zone where I end up spilling my heart out onto the bar as those pretty lights sparkle above me.  

I think maybe it's because Murio's doesn't impose any kind of predetermined vibe on their patrons--they embrace whoever you feel like being that night. You can relax or you can act out--Murio's will love you just the same, unconditionally. A love I'll accept, happily, for all my days in this city.
author: Meredith C.

description: WHAT HAPPENED!?! This place used to be great but they put in floor to ceiling windows in the front and got rid of the pinball machine! And they got rid of the dank, THE DANK!!! The only good thing is the new jukebox, it looks cool but I will not be drinking here again!
author: Fred F.

description: Great drinks and atmosphere, drunk bartender who over charged us then argued about it and angrily slammed the tab down in front of us. What a joke.
author: Evan D.

description: Not to busy on a friday night and a great place to wait for a table at cha cha cha's or Prada 22 also tv with the giants game on at the moment !
author: Miguel P.

description: Can't say much about the night shift here, but we stopped on a recommendation from a guy at Amoeba for a beer. The place is huge inside, but there was only about 10 people total at the bar. The bartender was awesome. He was total California bro, but not like a douchey East Coast bro. He was super friendly, gave us a ton of recommendations to check out around the Haight and had a bangin' playlist going. Prices are decent and that's about all you need to know about this place.
author: Joshua C.

description: Great place for an afternoon cocktail and people watching.  Bar tender was super nice and made a solid vodka tonic.
author: Theresa G.

description:
My friend got punched in the face at this place some years back from a drunk dude who we didn't know but didn't like my friend's face. 
Dive.  Yup.
author: Kev M.

description: Came here on a Friday night.  Fairly crowded, nothing crazy. Drinks were alright, but the service was exceptional. The bartender Nick was not only attentive, but I saw him working his butt off during lulls between customers. Of this is the service I get here every night, I will be back tomorrow.
author: Chelsea G.

description: Love me some Nick . Best nipples in town . Make sure he is working before you head there .
author: eric d.

description: Went here after bad experience at cha cha cha bartender was fast friendly and plain awesome. Drinks were good got super drunk ambience is welcoming! They check id so no idiot kids in there! -1 star for it being slightly dead on a sat night but then again it was memorial day weekend
author: Aminah H.

description:
Perfect dive bar

This place was the headquarters for a scavenger hunt we attended.  Lots of fun.  This place is cool.   a true dive bar, has the total feel. Located in the lower haight.  the bartender is cool, he was loud and all over the place. Drinks, being slung everywhere, the pl;ace was loud.  perfect Dive bar.

had lots of fun doing the scavenger hunt....
author: Nic C.

description:
There's no point in asking, you'll get no reply...

Remember that episode of the Simpsons where Moe remodels his bar and starts calling it Meaux's, hoping to draw a younger crowd?

That seems to be what happened here.

I give you... the new Murieaux's Trophy Room!

I'm sure there's a perfectly valid explanation for the stark remodeling that took place, but it seems like they went a bit too far.

I think there's something missing here now.

Some grimy bit of atmosphere.

More girls seem to come here than before, it seems.  Or at least, more of a certain type of girl seems come here now, and consequently maybe less of another.

You can still park yourself at the bar in the early evening and strike up a random conversation with a stranger.  I think that was a crucial element of what made this place a fixture on the local scene in it's previous incarnation.  

The old jukebox was like a shrine to punk, metal and trashy rock.

I didn't get a good look at the new jukebox, but it appears to now be a vintage-looking floor standing box with a 50's retro thing going on, and no particular taste in music being catered to.  

There was a small mixing console tucked discreetly into a corner beside the bar, implying there is still some kind emphasis on music, however.  

They still carry beers like Pliny The Elder and Blind Pig on tap, which is nice.  Of course, there's a chance that the newer bartenders don't know what those are.  I saw one of them start making a Bloody Mary once when a guy walked up and ordered a Pliny.

The big windows now flood the front area with daylight, which glints winsomely off all the new, shiny, brushed metal surfaces.  There are trophies of various types lining the shelves behind the bar, playing on the name as decorating theme.  

I guess this is still a comfortable, convenient place to stop in for a beer or two, but the overall brightness and shininess kind of robs it of the distinct ambiance it once had, however.

This place used to be a squalid yet lively dive bar, and now they've cleaned it up and made it pretty.  

Pretty vacant.

And we don't care.
author: Gopal R.

description:
Let's be clear: Dive bars are my favorite. You won't catch me bitching about the lack of ambiance or the service at most places. I like it chill, unpretentious, and quiet enough to hear my friends. 

However...

Walked in last night with my husband. It was 8 pm, there were maybe 10 patrons and it was half empty at the bar. After two minutes, we realized that the (lusciously busty and happy to lean over while serving so that all could admire) bartender was too busy doing shots at the other end of the bar to be bothered to notice we had no drinks in front of us. No one was demanding her attention. Two more minutes passed, and there was a loud thunk that could have been a top heavy bar stool hitting the floor. Nope. It was a top heavy patron who had fallen backwards off his stool, landed on the back of his head, unconscious (his eyes were unblinking, glazed and open). It took four guys to get him up while My husband hovered over the phone ready to call 911. Once he was up, we decided to leave since we hadn't even been glanced at. As we do, we overhear the boozy bartender lackadaisically slur, "is his head ok?" No. No, it's not. The sound it made bouncing off the floor made that obvious. 

She should be fined and fired for serving him. 

We won't be back. Bummer. We went down to the bridge-and-tunnel-set Hobson's instead, which was fine.
author: paige m.

description:
Can understand the upset folks below after a remodel of their favorite dive, but I'm a local and I love it! I think the Haight has enough of the old school dive bars to go around, and a little remodel never hurt anyone. Let's be honest, the remodel won't last forever and soon enough, it will be back at it's old divey dive status.

Great place to bring your Off the Grid food when it's cold and windy, and also home of hot bartender Dan. The poor guy dealt with a group of crazy ladies pre-bachelorette weekend and was a true gent. A great establishment, happy to have in the neighborhood and with some great eye candy.
author: Kate V.

description:
My friends and I came here on a Monday afternoon to hang out and relax.  It was my last day in SF before returning home, and the place was really inviting with cute decor and plenty of space for us to sprawl out in the back. 

Their happy hour was really good as well.  I was happy to discover they had bloody mary's for $5 - how can a girl pass that up.  Even better was the mix and drink snacks that it came with.  The bartender prepared a tasty, spicy bloody complete with lots of olives and a pickled asparagus spear.  SO YUM!!  Not gonna lie, I totally had 4 of these and thanks the bartender for her awesome bloody mary making skills. 

My friends enjoyed a few beers and sodas (not everyone drinks, yo!)

The pool table was really tempting, but chatting with friends you don't see every day was more important.  However, as a pool player, the table looked well kept - so I would come back and check it out the next time I'm in SF.
author: Jaci H.

description: Really nice bar in SF, has a pool table. Cocktails start at $10 and beer on tap starting at $8.00. Hung out in back area with tables booth chairs
author: Lauren G.

description:
I've lived in the Haight for the last four years and I've seen this bar change from that lovable dive in which you might get stabbed, either by a regular or a well-worn bar stool, to the slightly trendy, slightly hipster, well decorated hotspot it's become since the remodel 2 years ago.  I like this bar.  It's a good bar.  It still feels like a neighborhood bar, in spite of its shiny new decor.  The cocktails are unpretentious and tasty, the beer selection is always good.  It's so good, in fact that a friend and I came here on the last day of SF Beer week 2014 to get a taste of the coveted Russian River Pliny the Younger.  It was also among the worst experiences either of us have ever had at a bar.  

We knew that Monday was when the keg was going to be tapped.  My friend had the day off and got there around noon to see when it was going to happen.  6 was when it was supposed to happen and my friend hung around, alone at first, until I was off work and met her at around 4.  We both spoke to the bartender about how crazy Pliny tapping is, how annoying it is when everyone's asking about it, even when the sign out front says "Pliny tapping at 6."  We joked and agreed with her about how overhyped this beer probably is, but that we've had yet to try it so we just wanted to cross it off our list.

I've often been in when Alma is tending bar, and she's been a capable enough bartender.  We bantered a bit that day, and at the point I arrived, she knew my friend's name and understood why the two of us were there.  We were having a great time joking with the others who'd been sitting at the bar for hours hoping to claim the same goal.  By the time 6 hit, the bar was packed, with hands waving in the air, everyone trying to get a taste from the pony keg the bar had been allotted.  

In any situation such as this, one would think that the 'tender would do some serious triage, attending to those bar patrons who've been sitting at the bar for a few hours first, then taking orders from those who clearly pushed their way upon the bar in only the last few minutes.  It was the exact opposite of what happened.  She made two meager sweeps of the bar, passing up several of those sitting at the bar in favor of others who had just arrived, often without even the mildest of acknowledgment.  Both times she came by our end, I flagged and waved, asked for two servings, got a nod, and... nothing.  The second time she cam around, the same, only this time our neighbors helped out, telling her that my friend and I had been waiting to be served.  She, looked, nodded and... nothing.  She returned to the tap, began serving others, again.  Seconds later, reaching for more glasses to serve other patrons... Foam... 

The Pliny was gone, neither my friend nor I getting served, while several others around us, who had pushed and crowded around, were given 4, 6, 8 servings.  Many of the people sitting at the bar didn't get served.  Even after mentioning, "Hey, what gives? We've been here for hours," all we got was a hapless shrug and the most insincere of apologies.  To be fair, it was gone, but to have been so blatantly ignored was bordering on gross incompetence.  

Again I like this bar, I'll go back, but I'll either walk right out if I see Alma behind the bar or insist for another tender to help me.  You should, too.  If you see a short, olive-skinned woman with long black hair behind the bar, leave.  Wait for other bartenders to be there, they're far better at their jobs.
author: Lewis M.

description:
Murio's....Oh, how I miss you!

I used to work right across the street, and go there with friends/co-workers for pau hana (after work drink). I actually got the second drunkest I've ever been there....whew....crazy night.....ANYWAY...If you're a people-watcher like me, this is a great place....Though, while people-watching, you might get punched in the face by someone that doesn't appreciate being looked at....................at all. The drinks are strong and affordable. The best and worst of San Francisco's bartenders work here...You can go during the day and be totally ignored by some hipster dude that thinks he is WAY too cool for YOUR tip!....Then, go back that night to get the friendliest service from the hottest female you've ever laid eyes on!....Either way, Murio's is gonna be a TRIP!
author: T. G.

description:
Used to be a dive,but no longer. It looks more like a marina bar with small tables and a large glass front.
At least they kept the pool table. But I will miss the telephone booth.

However bathrooms are 100% better if you are in need so keep that in mind. But you won't find any of the locals here.
author: Timothy W.

description: Visiting from la with my gf and we started our night here. Stayed way longer than I expected. The  bar is kinda divey but pretty nice. There was only one bartender but you wouldn't even notice cause he was so damn fast. All n all good times at this joint. Highly recommend it.  Cheers.
author: Esteban C.

description: Fun little "dive" bar! Its like an upscale dive, if that exists? Anyway, had good service, good drinks, and their drink specials for the day were tasty. A good spot for people watching. It appears they are pet friendly, someone had their cute dog. Area with couches in the back looks like a nice place to hang out with friends.
author: Amy R.

description:
Where is the lingerie? I walked into what used to be one of my favorite dive bars to find this newly redecorated and rather pretty little shop. It has lots of lovely seating areas for your companion(s) to wait as your browse and a fancy little bar right where the old one used to be. The pool table is even still there but I can't find where they've put all the fancy underwear for sale. What kind of fancy shop is this if I can't find the merchandise?

As much as I loved the old place, I have to say, "bravo" on the new bathrooms. So, "Bravo."

Oh, and be careful to not hit yourself on the big ornament thing in the back. Oucharoo!
author: Loli L.

description:
Being from New York, this is exactly the type of crunchy place I try to avoid, but I embraced the SF/HA culture and enjoyed my two trips to Murios. 

Haighlighted by the pints of Pliny and pool table, it's a good time.
author: John E.

description:
I always love stopping into Murio's when I'm in SF.  I miss the old dive-y Murio's, but the renovations certainly don't keep me away.  I definitely prefer drinking here in the middle of the day when the crowd is nearly nonexistent and I can just sit back and relax.  This place seems to be packed with hipsters at night and the dj will drive you crazy with his loud music.  Kids these days...  

This place makes me feel like an old man.  I drink in the daylight hours and I think the music is too loud.  Awesome.
author: Todd S.

description:
You know, I remember walking down Haight on my way to Amoeba and looking over to Murio's and thinking it must be full of 1pm drunks inside!

So, the day I was here, I was just out of options. I didn't want to go to Kezar, or Milk, or Alembic, so what the hell! I was celebrating something special as well!

So after getting ID's I walked in and to my surprise, either Murio's just got re-decorated about a year ago, or it was always like this and I never noticed! It's second to being the fanciest bar on upper Haight! It had such a romantic vibe! Yes, Upper Haight bar. Yes, you read it. Not a dive bar, not even 1pm drunks lingering. Mostly couples or big groups, hell, not even gay it seemed.

I was amazed by the decor. Something about it just felt so romantic. Go here for a date or something...take your girlfriend here and kiss her in the backroom.
author: Alexia R.

description:
Ended up here after getting off work early and finding that not only was Hobson's Choice closed, but so was every other bar along the way.

Inside the pretty dark bar, the world cup was on multiple tvs, and there was a decent amount of people for the time of day.  Maybe because everything else was closed.  It was a nice surprise to find that happy hour not only started at 12pm, but went all the way until 7.

They have a good selection of beers, including some semi-rare Russian River Brewery ones on tap-- Pliny the Elder and Blind Pig.  I had a glass of the Pliny, and eventually a bloody mary.  

The bloody mary was pretty good, definitely not just some Mrs. T mix.  There was a good amount of horseradish in it, and it came with not just a green olive, but a green bean and asparagus spear as well.  Pretty tasty!  And couldn't be beat at only $5-6.  Not stingy on the booze either.

The bartenders seemed pretty nice there.  I'd go back if I was looking for a drink around that time again, but something about the dark atmosphere kinda throws me off.
author: Jon B.

description:
A great Hole in wall watering hole. 

Fun atmosphere. 

and Cheap drinks in sf? Score! 

If you have a particular libation you would like, they can do it. 
if you have a particular liquor you are craving, but don't know how you want it... they will take care of you. 
it's great for an indecisive person like me! :)
author: Judy N.

description: Visiting from Houston  and was pleased to hear some old school hip hop so I wandered into this bar. One bartender was a total douche and glared at me after I accidentally took the wrong shot (he placed it in front of me, so I drank it) and harrassed me for taking his "good tequila". But, I got about 5 min of quality twerking in then went on to some classier joints down the street. 2 stars for playing Tupac.
author: Erin G.

description: My second living room while I was to chef school in 92 to 93. Awesome and friendly staff. Great strong drinks. Juke box is awesome as well. Great place to meet hot girls with tattoos and great attitudes towards sharing heh. Love this place.
author: Ray S.

description:
Somebody needs to update the entire album on here for Murio's..... it sho' doesn't look like most of the posted photos no mo'. 

It's really pretty now though... I'm like a flyyy flying towards the lit lantern. Before it used to have one of the nastiest bathrooms at a bar in SF (next to Zeitgeist maybe). Now.. I don't know, guess I'll have to pay a visit just to check out the bathroom.

If you don't like being spotted at a bar, you better not go. That's right, they made big a WINDOW out front now....patrons are now on display.
author: Faffy L.

description:
Oh Damn I think I'm in Love!

Definitely a dive bar gem!  It was Sunday night when my friend took us here after a dinner at Cha Cha Cha's a couple of doors down.  There's one pool table and a sign up board where you can put your name down to play some pool.  They have music playing and there's plenty of places to sit.  They do have dollar beer night, which is awesome, and the drinks weren't too highly priced either.  It wasn't horribly packed and there were random people walking in at different times during the night. I think a little bit after midnight all the barstools were taken up so this place gets decent business - even on a Sunday night!  

One of the girls in my group wanted a group picture and this random girl offered to take it.  I thought that was pretty cool of her...  and then as she is about to take a picture she pulls down her tube top and totally flashes us with her booby!! whoah! I think my friends and I got a little shocked but we all laughed it off.  Entertaining I guess?

Of course.... not everyone may see it the same way I do.  I'm just a sucker for dives with good vibes, a chill atmosphere, nice and interesting characters, good prices and good drinks!  And good-looking bartenders (whether straight or not) doesn't hurt either.  :)
author: Mercy D.

description:
As a person who spent a lot of time at Murio's around 2000, it pains me to say that I actually like the redesign. Roy is right that Murio's really was the last excellent dive bar in that area and definitely had its own vibe to it. Now it may as well be any bar, but I don't necessarily think that's a bad idea.

First, the bartenders still kick ass. They are funny, nice but still have a biting sense of humor and know how to mix you a drink.

Second, bathrooms. Ok guys let's be honest--how many times did you go to Murio's because you had too much to drink at Magnolia or somewhere else and you really needed to pee? I think in 1999 that's how I actually discovered the place in the first place. Well now you can do that in three very clean bathrooms in a bar that's still kind of cool even if it's no Zeitgeist.

Third, they have Pliny on tap. That definitely means something.

Fourth, the pool table is still there and I have tons of memories attached to that thing.

Anyway, if you didn't go back in the day you'd probably think--oh this is just a nice mostly clean, dark-ish bar. If that's how you approach it good for you. But for me it'll always be Murio's even with the new facelift.
author: Paul C.

description:
It always starts so innocently. You're minding your business and taking a stroll along the Upper Haight on a weekday. You are perhaps thinking of the Gaza Strip situation or your hair or about calling that dude who lived in that flat on Fell a few years back because he was smokin' hawt. You smile wistfully at the entrance to Golden Gate Park. You pass by McDonald's and Amoeba. You step over panhandlers with dogs and cardboard pleas. You are not phased. You are a seasoned, jaded city rat.

You see the chalkboard sign in front of Murio's that boasts a liberal definition of happy hour. Their happy hour lasts from noon to 7 and they, the good people of Murio's, will provide you with a well drink or beer of your choice for just three dollars. You say, "Why thank you, Murio's! I think I will have one to wet my whistle."

Then many pours later, you find yourself cradling your chin very close to the bar and finding the Fox Soccer Channel as captivating as a telenovela. The bartenders, some of the most sarcastic and friendly folks in the city, are cracking you up. Your walk has lasted several hours, and most of it took place from the barstool to the bathroom, you lush.

But is there any better place than Murio's to come to this realization about yourself? There is not.
author: Kimberly V.

description: Great nice looking dive bar. Descent selection on spirits and GREAT BARTENDERS. No I am not related or go out with any of the staff. There just very good staff.
author: Adam B.

description:
Longest trek to a DYL.  Ever.  At least, in my relatively short history of DYLs.

So the night started off interesting- walking in the Prop 8 march.  As the lovely Pilar and I knew our adoring fans were waiting for us, we veered off and attempted to get on the N-judah.  Which we did...and then it stopped.  But HEY- yet ANOTHER person who I haven't seen since high school was on the SAME TRAIN.  Spooky.

We ended up jumping off and hiking the rest of the way, because spending the evening trapped with the woman who would NOT SHUT UP is not the way to go.

And then we entered Murio's.  While I wasn't impressed at first, the more time I spent here allowed me to scope it out and acclimate.  The drinks were so-so, and while I know it's to stay true to the "dive bar" atmosphere, why oh why can't these places take credit cards?  I hate carrying around cash, I'm a skinny white girl who most likely will get mugged soon.  Although they did have a cool sign behind the bar explaining WHY they don't take credit...but I can't remember what it says.

I liked the christmas lights on the ceiling, although I wasn't impressed with the sturdiness (or lack thereof) of our table.  

If there's another DYL here, I MIGHT go...but it's highly unlikely I'll trek out here on my own.

Great to meet some new yelpers, though!
author: Pam S.

description:
Where is the dive bar that I know and love?! Where do I now get my $2 Hamms? 

I haven't been here to see the new-remodel so I honestly don't know how I feel about this "new" Murio's yet. But iI'm all for re-vitalizing the neighborhood. If it's good for the goose, it's probably good for the gander.
author: Melissa N.

description:
It was my first time. I'd never done it before, but I'd spent all day getting little suggestions talking me into it. 

"You'll LOVE it." 
"It'll hurt a little at first, but you'll get into it."
"Just relax, it'll hurt less."

I agreed. I was a little apprehensive, a tad nervous, but a bit excited. Almost giddy.

I am, of course, talking about my first DYL. Which went down at Murio's. Home of nicely priced drinks, a kickass jukebox, crap on the floor, and doggies gently lapping the ladies' room toilet. Oh, and the pool table where Tanner handed me my pale Irish ass.

Great wee dive bar in the heart of the Haight.

And yes, I was careful, and wore protection.
author: Gary E.

description:
Friday night started out a little hectic, in that on my way to the city my longtime mohawked-out friend from military school (I love how they breed us to rebel aftewards) called and asked if I could help her pick up her new furry little animals in Millbrae. After a half hour of breaking down the cage and it's components, we drive up to the city and park near the bar. 

Then, the craving hit. Again. McDonalds. OMG. 

I don't know if it was because I was reminded of Quinn's Zombie Movie Night and me scarfing down a Big Mac (they said bring your own food!), or if it was the temptation of salty, greased up fries I could delightfully nom on...but the craving was there and I had to have it. 

So I walked into Murio's with my hand in a McDonalds bag, eating fries and a Southern Style Chicken Sandwich. Drinking a Stella. 

I give this place three stars because for most of the night, my friends would come over and say, "is it self serve? Because I don't see a bartender here." 

Also, invisible negative stars for the dog who was my best friend up until I finished eating my chicken sandwich, at which point the MOMENT I put the last bite in my mouth, he got up and left. Everybody uses me. Even the dog.
author: Jaime L.

description:
Ok look, if I go in a shithol...errrr... dive bar and I order a martini straight up with olives and you serve it in a whiskey glass, that's a problem.

If, later on in the evening, a pool ball is accidentally hit a little too forcefully, flies across the room, and hits said martini so that the glass explodes upon impact at which point you hand me a broom and tell me to clean up, it's no longer just a problem:  it's a fucking issue.

Fuck you, Murio!
author: David O.

description: I never made it by in its former incarnation, but I can say the end result is pretty decent. Bar on the right with cool lights, a few tables on the left, pool table at the middle-back, and then a cool lounge zone at the very rear. That was occupied by a birthday party reservation on my visit- slightly annoying for me, but good to know you can book that space. Crowd/vibe hard to pin down for now, but overall comfortable.
author: Thomas R.

description: When did I get so old that I prefer a dingy dive bar to a "cooler" bar? Well anyways, my partner and I hopped into Murios for one drink after having dinner in the Haight on a random Thursday evening and it was everything a dive bar should be. Clean but looks like it's not, pool table in the back, patrons older than 21, reasonably priced drinks, cool bartenders, and a "welcome all" vibe. We were able to play a couple of games of pool before we had to give up the table to other people so that was pretty cool. We ended up having drinks there for the rest of the night, we were so comfortable we didn't want to leave right away. All in all, it's a cool spot to have a few drinks.
author: Melina M.

description:
So I end up spending a lot of time in the Haight, mostly waiting for friends at Amoeba.  No, not waiting to score "nuggets" or whatever else those people are pushing (There's no wait for that anyway).

So I wandered over to Murio's.  Yeah, it's Dive-y with a capital "D" but the bartenders couldn't be nicer, from the obviously lost tourists ("Where's Golden Gate Park?"), to the "regulars" that come in and pay with quarters ("Don't worry, I tip in dollars").  Yeah, they do Happy Hour from 11-7 and beers are $3.50.

Note that Murio's was a tennis shop back in the day, thus the giant racket behind the bar.
author: Michael M.

description:
Went to this place rather early in the evening, sat down at the bar, and had an apple cider. As I was looking around I noticed that they had caricatures all over the ceiling with different sayings and suck. This made being in the bar so much more humorous. Wish I knew the gals name behind the bar, she was sweet.

would come back here again
author: Lisa W.

description: It's a nice, chill place to hang out in the neighborhood, pool table and all. Not 100% sold on it or the crowd though, so we'll have to see what I think next time.
author: Rowena L.

description:
I have spent a many afternoons in this lovely refreshment stand.
Hamms for $2. Pabst on draft. Full bar. The Irish coffee is the best one I ever tasted. 

It is pretty much a must stop if you spend the day in SF. I can't think of many people who do not enjoy a day at amoeba music, followed by a couple drinks in a dark bar with a good juke box.

maybe that says something of the crowd I tend to run in...
author: Rossi H.

description:
I was physically attacked in Murio's, because my buddy and I were wearing Tigers gear during the World Series. On top of that, when my eye was bleeding and swollen, the bartender, who was shitface drunk, DENIED ME SOME ICE. He told me I was in the wrong place. This is after I had been there for a few hours and bought a couple drinks, with commensurate tips.

A bunch of actual humans finally stepped in and helped us out. A police report was filed. I and friends and co-workers had been going here for years. 

Lastly, they have a jukebox that is plugged in and lit up and will take your money, but is not connected to any speakers or anything, so it won't even play your music! If that isn't the epitome of underhanded and shady -- at best -- I don't know what is.

This shit hole was better when it was a shithole!
author: Steve I.

description: Used to be a great dive bar. Closed down and reopened as the douchiest place in the Haight. Seriously, the ambience would be best-described as classic Marina. Didn't even bother ordering a drink when I walked in.
author: Steve K.

description:
LOVE this place.

After lunch, my friend suggested we pop into Murio's for a Bloody Mary.  I'm always on the hunt for a great Bloody Mary, and most places inevitably disappoint.  

Not Murio's!  Oh man.  They know how to mix a Bloody Mary!  Just the perfect amount of heat and tomato with all the perfect accoutrements!

The is the dive bar of dive bars and if I were you, I would pop in there on a rainy San Francisco day, order a Bloody Mary and enjoy.
author: Sara B.

description:
Yeah, I dig this place. Could it be due to the residual ganja aroma, man?

That, and there are some damn good billiard playing dudes here.

I guess that's the reason for the trophy crap all over the joint. 
But, they also have a damn good jukebox. And, if you look up at the ceiling, you can find some pretty funny cartoon artwork; coulda swore I found a pic of myself - never mind. 

I like this place because it's not crowded. The people here are chill (wonder why). Spot cool doggies that are allowed to wonder in and out.

So, I don't think you will like it here. I'm here. You won't like me; I'm old and hate hipsters.
author: Kara B.

description: They have Pliny the Elder! Nough said! Good mix of neighborhood bar and nice atmosphere. Fresh sqeezed juice in their drinks.
author: Matthew K.

description:
No...you didn't, you wouldn't dare.......you did!!!!!!!!  NO!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

First the GAP, now this.  I remember during the dot com era when all the window displays were so perfect, like a wannabe Chestnut street.  It was a scary time in the Haight, but slowly, history prevailed and the landmark Haight perservered.

WTH did you do to my beloved Murio's, the last real holdout of trashy historical dive bars left in the upper Haight?  It was a toilet, it was a drunktank, it was edgy, it was freaky, it was real...I loved it!  I miss it.  In the words of Sally in the Peanuts Halloween episode where they cut up the pumpkin in preparation for carving, "You didn't tell me you were going to KILL it!!!!"

I should have known something was up when I first saw all that wood covering the front recently.  I figured they were doing some minor changes or exterior mods, but never in a million years expected this.  Have to admit though, they did an amazing job!!!  Honestly, the first time I saw it, I did a real double-take.  I literally took a step back and looked at the outside to make sure I really was at the right place.  Visually, it is pretty darn impressive.  Whoever handled the re-do more than accomplished what they were paid to do.  Hell, whoever did it was a G.D. magician!  This place looks so nice inside.  The makeover is gorgeous and had I been blindfolded and brought in, I would have sworn up and down that there is no way it could have been the same place.  And yet, with all the cleanup and upgrading, we lost a little part of ourselves along the way.  The crowd is obviously very different now and the place looks and feels nothing like what it had been, both good and bad.  

I have countless memories of drinking here over the years, in the day and the night, fun times shooting pool with wild alcohol abandon.  There must be a ton of lost souls in the area...where will they all go now?

A cynical friend of mine said that if he had wanted to go to a place like this, he would have gone to the marina (or perhaps Martin Mack's) and that there are plenty of places like this already, so why kill a historic dive?  Personally, I  really like how it looks in there, but only wish it had been anywhere else on that block.  I also have serious doubts if the customer base in the area can support what the new decor of this establishment aspires to be.  Curious to see which way all this will go once the place finds itself and the customer base finds a natural level.  What type of crowd will frequent this place?  Only time will tell.

Like they always say, change is inevitable and there is nothing as inevitable as change.  As to whether it actually can be considered progress remains to be seen.   Popped in here for a quick drink the other night, but didn't stay long since I was too shocked.  I still have mixed feelings so will keep my review rating exactly where it is until I go back a couple more times.  

Like I said earlier about Sally in the Peanuts cartoon..."You didn't tell me you were going to KILL it!!!!"  What next?  Lucky 13?
author: Roy N.

description:
murios is MY BAR. 
I've been frequenting the place for almost 7 years.
we recently moved out of the city so it's off my path now, but it's one great dive bar.

there have bee epic bartenders there. from jason to mike, to eric. 
the owners is the nicest sweede on the planet. 

the people that come in and the people you meet are priceless. the juke box has always been great. from butt-rock to mexican pop.

there will always be a special place in my heart for murio's. 
and rest in peace water fall. (tim)
author: Brandon V.

description: They went and fucked it up. Sunlight should never be seen in a dive bar and now it looks like the typical Starbucks style of San Francisco "everybar".
author: Gregg D.

description:
This place is terrible since the redesign - no more punk rock jukebox and instead have decided to play some awful mix.  No more dive bar feel -looks like a yuppie bar. Even the bartenders look depressed and I can't blame them - I wouldn't want to be there either.

Sticking to the Gold Cane and other bars that still have a somewhat of a real feel to them.  I want my Haight back!
author: Mark K.

description:
I've changed my mind about this place. This bar really bums me out.

They are usually understaffed. One time I was here for dollar beer night and they just had one lady working the whole bar. I felt really bad for her because the place was packed.

This bar is also absolutely filthy and crackheads/bums like to hang out in here too.
author: Rachel H.

description: The last cool bar in the upper haight has turned into another yuppie tourist joint.  What was once a jukebox with the Reverend Horton Heat has been replaced with trendy "unst-unst-unst" music.  It's not only a remodel, but a finger in the air to anyone who once hung out here saying "Stay away locals, we're only appealing to tourists now."  Don't bother unless you're here from the mid-west and only want to see the Fisherman's Wharf version of San Francisco.
author: Joshua W.

description:
thought the place really needed to facelift, but this may have been a little too much....  the new front windows bring in so much light (with the walls reflecting), it's tough to call this a dive bar anymore...

all they needed to do was get the gross smell out of there!
author: Colin L.

description:
After Opera in the Park, we need a drink...and what better place to quench our classy/thisty selves than Murio's Trophy Room in the Upper Height. 

Several bottles of wine were polished off at GGP but we were just buzzed. Still though, a situation like this calls for a tall boy of PBR...actually 4-5 of them. The last ones standing were me, Theron, Adrian, Nadja and Jessica. Unbelievably, the girls kept up w/ the guys despite being 1/2 our size. The patrons of the place are eclectic. They range from dirty hipster to dirty hippie to dirty biker to dirty scenster. I felt right at home. 

The highlight of the day...or was it night already?: 
Jessica goes up to some gorgeous woman and asks, "If you're interested, I'm sitting w/ three guys who think you're hott." Most girls I know will claim to be a great wing man, but I have not seen much to justify this boast. I saw it that time. 

Now as for the rest of our com-padres. After they left, one of them took a "nap" close to the park. I later found out that she woke up surrounded by traveling homeless Height kids and their dog. I guess drinking a gallon of PBR didn't sit well w/ her. As for Goose, she called in the next day claiming that me and Theron are "bad influences". Psha, I say....psha.
author: Angelo F.

description: NICE bartenders ,friendly place,great prices and it has a pool table. I choose this place over every other spot on haight st!!!
author: Kristopher M.

description:
So this is going to sound bad, but it is the truth...

This is my go to place after my weekly doctor appointment.

Well, I don't go every week, or even most weeks, but if I'm going to a bar after my doctor appointment, this is where I go. 

The service is mediocre, but the drinks are cheap. It is next door to Amoeba and Cha Cha Cha, so you can grab a quick drink before a show or before dinner without spending all the loot in your purse. PLUS it is great for people watching...I mean, come on...it IS The Haight.
author: Chia C.

description:
This place was fun.

We'd started the night with a slightly smaller group (6) at The Alembic, but some Mac and cheese and fries later, the growing size of our asses told us we  should move on.  Ended up here because the giant sign beckoned to our group of 10.

Cheap beer but cash only.  $4 might not be super cheap for a pint of beer, but after $15 martini's and $12 for a basket of fries with mayo for dipping, I'll take $4 stella anyday.  When we left, we heard the doorman say "well, there goes half the bar.".
author: Kathleen W.

description:
I actually visited Murio's quite a while ago, on my last trip to the bay in August.  Thinking back, I am amazed at how drunk I was on this Saturday afternoon before even entering this fine establishment.  But that's also the main reason as to why I wasn't able to Yelp about it until now- I could not, for the life of me, remember the name of this place until Jessica T was gracious enough to Yelp it and bring back a flood of memories for me!

My day began innocently just a few miles away at the Toronado.  After a good number of pints here, we were on the bus to Amoeba Music to pick up some new jamz, as well as some proper old school funk.  A friend suggested we stop into Murio's afterward, to keep the buzz going.

I was greeted with an ice cold, refreshing can of Pabst Blue Ribbon which was presented nicely in a brown paper bag.  How can you say no to that?  Anytime I have the opportunity to drink out of a paper bag, I jump at it.  Whether I need that drink or not, if it's in a bag, I'll put it in my mouth.  And when it's a house special, for a low, low price- even better!

I vaguely remember some hot tunes pumping out of the juke box, making a relatively docile daytime crowd bob their heads and sing in unison the chorus of Stairway to Heaven.

I definitely plan on making another trip to Murio's, and I hope the next time I'll remember a little more of it.  Looking at some of the fan photos, I was thinking to myself "so THAT'S what the place looked like!".  Ahh, the wonderment of alcohol, you gotta love it.
author: Sean L.

description:
Me- "I'll have a Maker's, no ice"
Bartender- "OK, that'll be $6"
Me- (Double-take)

In conclusion, If I could get a glass of Maker's anywhere for the price of a beer, I would have a criminal record.
author: Ryan V.

description:
Used to frequent Murio's a lot more than I have recently, but it's always a good place when I can't think of anywhere else to go.  Good tunes are always playing and they have Jello shots for a buck.  rock on.  One of the bartenders is kind of a dick, but I think that his "thing" - one time he was showing off and whipped a bottle cap off - it smacked me on the face next to me eye...I asked him to buy me a shot to make up for nearly blinding me...he didn't see the humor in it.  Whatever...I still go there.

Update: no more Jell-o shots served here.
author: Mac M.

description:
I went here last night after an absence of several years ... even though I live nearby ... and I wondered why I had stayed away so long.

It's the perfect dive bar. Nice bartenders, great jukebox, interesting patrons, good conversation, a World Series game and ... a happy hour that lasts from noon to 7 p.m. I enjoyed my $3 dirty martinis.
author: Kim C.

description:
OK....Murios is reopened and I can report that I have been there twice for drinks.  The interior has been gutted, the ceiling lifted, and the walls replaced with very modern looking wallcoverings.  There are fancy light fixtures and a loungy area in the back to hang out.  That said, it is still a BAR, and a place for cocktails.  
YES, as reported, the Pliny the Elder is no long on tap.  HOWEVER, the bar does have Blind Pig IPA on tap still, which is also made by Russian River Brewing Co.  This gives me hope that the dearest Pliny will return in the near future (Haighters, you can find Pliny on tap at Tornado and at the Page).  
From a price perspective, it does seem as if it is a little bit more expensive.  The first time I went we drank some Blind Pigs, and I believe those were in the standard 4-5 dollar a pint range.  But I was, um, not sober when I walked in there.  
I went last night and had a few Manhattans while my wife had red wine.  The wines have been upgraded it looks like to decent brands--$7 a glass with a nice pour.  My Manhattans (using Bulleit bourbon) were also healthy on the booze and clocked in at $7 per drink.  Seems like a bit more than I remember paying at the old Murios, but still not bad at all...
For now, the place seems to have kept its roots while upscaling a bit.  I will keep an eye on this one.
author: Blake W.

description: I loved this bar. It was the dirty dive bar where people would tell there children not to walk to close to the door way when passing. The type of place you couldn't see how pretty or ugly the Pearson next to you was with or without your drunk goggles on. No windows for descent folk to judge your drunken ways while you just leave net working and your responsible life aside for the night. It would be hard to act so bad to be 86 d from this joint. Well not anymore. It looks really posh and clean with big windows and well lit. I'll get back to you when I give it a shot if they will still serve the likes of me a shot. Nick the bar tender is still there thank god and he is a riot.
author: Justine P.

description: Oh Murios. We go way back. Back when I was 17, thank you for never questioning my id. NICK!!! I love you and miss you. Thank you for all the awesome bar stool chats, cheap strong drinks, and hilarious antics.
