This is a great dingy dive bar with a good juke box, interesting characters, darts, pool tables, and a bathroom with a western theme swinging door. Nick, Kristin says hi to you an Autumn. (:
author: Chelsey G.

description: Once of my favorite bars in Upper Haight! Lots of room, great happy hour, and awesome vibe. The pool table is also a plus. I always have fun at Murio's.
author: Bridget B.

description:
With my mug, I don't have any delusions that pretty hipster bartenders will fawn over me; however, on the dreary afternoon that my associate and I skulked into this establishment, we were met with a murderous glare akin to that of a menstruating honey badger. The bar was nearly empty: one patron at the bar, and a table of four near the pool table, quietly conspiring. The bartender peeled her gaze away from her cell phone, looked up expectantly, and when it registered that we were not who she hoped we'd be, the change in her features was audible; you could HEAR her hopes crash to the grimy, wooden floor. She grunted a greeting. My friend and I saddled up and ordered two Pabst drafts, she pulled them, threw the coasters down on the bar, and slammed the two pints in front of us. Then, she went back to manically texting.

The bar itself was unremarkable. It could have been a bar on the southwest side of Chicago. Or Milwaukee. Or Boston: dark wood, Christmas lights, mirrors, artwork scrawled on napkins by patrons over the years, signs issuing various warnings (don't be an asshole, "Tip the Bartender, Bastards!"). For this reason alone, the atmosphere was friendly enough.

I grew up frequenting the bars of the southwest side of Chicago that Stuart Dybek wrote about in his stories in Coast of Chicago - the places that offered bowls of hard-boiled eggs and peanuts at the bar, the places that Polish, Italian, and Irish families spent Sundays commiserating with friends and family. I base the quality of an establishment like this by how quickly I can engage in a friendly conversation with the bartender or patron upon entering (usually about local sports, but not always), and I've applied that litmus test to neighborhood [read: "dive"] bars I've visited in all other cities throughout the country. For example, at Mr. Bing's on Columbus where we went the night before, Bruce, the Bartender, greeted us warmly and invited us in to watch the Giants game within 10 seconds of us walking in. We paid a LOT more for drinks that night, but stayed much longer... Hmmmmm... I bet you are wondering why...

Meanwhile at The Trophy Room, the jukebox was playing Radiohead's Kid A in its entirety, and I proceeded to try to convince my comrade that, despite his issues with any music recorded after 1975, this album was a damned good one. My efforts proved fruitless. Our conversation went from music to the temperature of the beer in drinking establishments (he commented to me that he felt his Pabst was warm. He bought the beer that day, so I had forfeited my complaining rights). He remembered hearing from a friend of his in Amsterdam that, on bottles of Heineken, there is a suggested temperature that the beer should be chilled, and that if it is any colder, it compromises the flavor. He asked the bartender, who at this time was busily chatting up a friend who had entered bar and took a seat near her at the end of the bar, if she might grab him a bottle of Heineken -that he wasn't going to drink it, but only use it for reference; however, in the middle of his explanation, she cut him of, "Yeah, yeah. I get it! I GET it!" She grabbed the bottle from the fridge and slammed it down in front of him.

Now, another of this bartender's friends had arrived, a ratty-haired, hipster chick with old school punk band patches neatly sewn or ironed onto her Gap jean jacket. She was cheerily served a 24 oz. can of Pabst Blue Ribbon - for $2, I should add. The prices, even for the middle of the day, were enough for us to subject ourselves to the bartender's abuse for one more pint. The young women chattered merrily, glowering at us, disaffected, whenever our conversation became a bit boisterous, as conversations are wont to do in gin mills.

We finished our beer, paid up, tipped the bartender much more than she deserved, and went across the street for a veggie burrito.

My overall impression: I spent the late 80's and early 90's mostly being ignored by hostile, hipster chicks with punk band patches on their jean jackets. I dated a few: not as special as they fancied themselves to be. I don't enjoy paying good money for that memory. Maybe I'm too old.
author: Daniel R.

description:
Typical dive bar...dirty, friendly bartender. Cheap pool with jacked up pool cues...all in all a perfect beginning to what became the impromptu San Francisco Vacation Pub Crawl of 2009 

One complaint, the drinks were a bit expensive considering the atmosphere...
author: Mia M.

description: Great bartenders, dogs are allowed, you can bring in food (Parada22 and Cha Cha Cha next door) and good beer - Pliny the Elder, Hopstoopid, and Supplication. Pool table, plenty of space, and good vibes.
author: Art V.

description:
Generally speaking, I'm an easy mark for most dive bars (hellooo, have you*met* me?), and when we found ourselves roundabout of the Haight and in the market for a cold one and a killer jukebox, and Murio's was only too happy to have us sidle in, order up our own version of high-octane sarsparilla (which, for the sake of discussion, we'll call 'Hoegaarden'), and quicker than you can say slack-jawed tourist, there I was pumping dollar bills into the jukebox.

Decent brew selection, easygoing staff, and over the strains of Pablo Picasso (thanks, Modern Lovers), we bled off into the dark recesses of the night.  And in the end, isn't that about appropriate for a dive?
author: Kevin N.

description: I live in the area but I haven't been by this spot until recently. It was clean, crowded but still had room to grab a seat with a friend and chat over a drink. I have no idea how this place use to be prior and how long they can keep up the good vibes but as long as they last I will continue to hit the place up. I like it.
author: Shanna T.

description:
As Matthew R (swooon) so eloquently pointed out in his review, "Murio's is a filthy, seedy dive bar". It is also a place where you will have beer spilled on your Christian Loubotains (wear non-designer here), you will be asked to flash your breasts, and if you're not careful you can be speared in your boney hips by a pool stick by a drunk guy who blames the assault on you instead of taking responsibility. What else to expect from a drunk wielding a four and a half foot stick? It comes with the territory here.

All of the downfalls considered, Murio's also happens to rock, even in the opinion of a girl who prefers wine bars and designer shoes (and bags. and clothes. and makeup...oh god!). I like to come here with the merry band of alcoholics I like to call my best friends. Probably because when one is drunk, one tends to think EVERYONE is their best friend. This should give you some idea of how much time we spend inebriated. I can come here and have my ass kicked at pool by Amir, drunk cry with Drue, and watch Starla charm the pants off of boys. Oh and smoke outside with two of the three mentioned above. It's gritty, it's greasy, and the bathroom is filthy. But all in a good way. Go there. Drink. Play pool. Just don't hit any girls with boney hips or ask them to flash their boobs and you'll be fine.
author: Autumn K.

description:
As Kevin N. mentioned below, I too, am easily satisfied by many a dive bar.  And this one was pretty right on.  Really, the main necessities include a dark-painted space, cheap beers, and a jukebox. Live bands are sometimes a plus too, but it's not a necessity...

Murio's is a major winner in the jukebox department. This alone is probably responsible for 1.5-2 stars.  I got to play some Cramps on the night I learned Lux Interior had died. I even chatted briefly with some fellow about the Cramps.  At that point I decided that knowing a little bit about/having seen the Cramps should probably be a requisite for entry into a certain type of dive bar.  

Threw a few dollars in and added on some Modern Lovers (and Kevin did too! Good taste, my friend!) as well as Radio Birdman.  

Now, I don't know about you guys here in SF, but in Michigan, Radio Birdman is not exactly found on every jukebox. Steve Miller Band would be more likely. Maybe even the Ramones, but not really Radio Birdman.

I enjoyed sitting in a bar, sipping cheap beer while listening to "I-94" without actually having to go outside and drive *home* on the real I-94 through the ice-n-snow!
author: mariah c.

description:
Well, its Friday night, we are hitting place to place in the HA neigborhood...Stopped in this little dig called Murios Trophy Room...Pretty cool spot. They have a SWEET jukebox that has all kinds of great music, stuff you probably forgot you liked. 
The bartender seems a bit busy, large bar with one dude workin...The first drink I got was weak, a bit disappointing. The second drink?..TOTALLY strong, wow dude, easy...
author: Michael E.

description:
I want to do a dive bar crawl where we all just come to Murios as soon as they open and stay. That would be a dirty nasty dive bar crawl. 

Stop one on the crawl would be in the back of the bar with a few strong drinks for a game of pool, since the daytime drinkers here are much more serious about verbally abusing each other over 10 or 12 cocktails than playing a game which requires some level of coordination. 

Stop two would be on the mismatched bar stools where you could down a few more drinks while engaging in conversation with people who will make you think you are visiting a circus sideshow rather than a bar. The upside is that the regulars, along with the wide array of Christmas lights, will cast a healthy glow on you that will make you look beautiful and not the least bit wasted!

Stop three would be the restrooms, which I recommend visiting with drink in hand. Since you are going to, at this point, be getting drunk enough to spill this is a prime place to do it for disinfectant purposes.

Stop four on this crawl will take you to the counter across from the bar where you can ceiling gaze before your vision becomes double and you can no longer appreciate the fine art caricatures, the large tennis racket and hidden trophys this place has provided for your viewing enjoyment. 

Stop five? The tables by the front door. By this time it should be getting dark out so this should be celebrated with a tall boy of PBR as you watch the hipsters and nighttime riff-raff take over the bar. 

The final stop on this dive bar crawl will undoubtedly be the floor, hence the term "crawl". This, my friends, is when the dirty nasty I was talking about earlier will truly come to life. This will also be the only time in the day, regardless of how you behave, that they may kick you out....but this, too, is debatable. 

Who's in??
author: Drue C.

description:
So we won the semis, and then we had some time to kill before the finals.  4 of us, slightly sweaty, in our jerseys, palming our own basketballs, looking for somewhere obvious to relax and watch the Lakers/Celtics game 5 . . . naturally we went to the Kezar, since we'd been playing at Kezar Gym, and it's y'know, right there.  It was also packed to the gills.  Ok - plan B . . . Murios!  

Game on TV - check
Sodas on tap - check
Weird people arguing with the bartender about whether they can use the bathroom without buying anything - check
Drunken woman slumped unconscious over her gin and tonic at the corner of the bar - check
Complete lack of internet reception on my iPhone - check
Other weird people hurling the bathroom key at the bartender - check

Based on this experience only (I have others in this place that were, how shall I say . . . calmer) - I conclude that Murio's is a great place for a part time jock and full time dork such as myself to relax and watch a basketball game on TV, if you find belligerent drunks and the dregs of the Haight Street Beat to be relaxing.

When I've come here just to play pool at night, I've found it much more hospitable.
author: Joe C.

description:
Fourth bar stool from the end: see that? That's my ass groove in that stool.

You might think the bartenders here are assHOLES. I've heard that from folks. Actually, if you think that, funny thing... 

Then YOU'RE the asshole. Take that! These dudes are cool, and I will defend them to the death. Nick the bartender is my favorite bartender in SF. Has been since I moved here, hasn't been outdone yet. He's a RIOT. He keeps the bar entertained with his dirty one-liners -- seriously, he NEVER misses a beat -- and my crazy old mom pointed out to me that that's what a good bartender does. He's a professional entertainer of sorts.

Okay, now you're saying, "wait a minute, you took your MOTHER to Murio's?" 

YES I DID, BIOTCHES! And she loved it. She talked about drinking tequila and puking with Nick all night long. I had to drag her out of there and lock her in her hotel room to get her to go to bed.

When I lived two blocks away, no one ever dragged me home. No one ever kicked me out, either. Even though they probably should have (like the night of the vodka-drinking contest: augh). That doesn't happen too often at Murio's. In fact, I've seen a lot of people throw up IN the bar. So hells yeah, it's kinda gross. But I also one time watched Nick tell a wasted girl who blew chunks that she was gonna clean it up herself. Talk about a look of disbelief. 

Believe it, chica. That's how they roll at Murio's. You're welcome to puke there, just clean it up yourself.

Kings of Leon in the jukebox? Check. Which lead to my first take-a-random-guy-home-from-a-bar-and-sleep-with-him experience (yes, not so long ago I had standards, people!). The next morning I found out he was 21, and had lied to me about his age. Which made me want to throw up, but that wasn't really any different from how I usually felt the morning after a Murio's night. So it was a wash. 

Okay -- I got laid by a hot 21 year old. It was a win!

Murio's rules!!!
author: Lisa T.

description:
I've come to the conclusion that I like my bars to stink a little.

Whether it's vomit, dog, body odor, or something unidentifiable yet slightly foul, I never fail to have a good time.  In fact, it almost seems like the smellier, the better.  Perhaps it's because my apartment smells bad, but I digress.

Not to say Murio's is all that smelly.  Murio's has pockets of smelliness, whether it's underneath the bar counter (no coat hooks, natch), in certain back corners or near booths, or near the front of the bar.  That might sound like a lot but they are genuinely isolated.  Besides, if you drink enough, you won't notice and it's not bad enough to really care anyway.

Tall boy PBRs, pool table, ample seating and an eclectic jukebox, all accompanied by well drinks for $4.50.  Dog-friendly too, apparently, especially for that cutie pie who frequently decided to lounge in the middle of the floor so that patrons may better appreciate him.
author: Sus... B.

description:
Wow. That's all I can say. I guess I'm not cool enough, or uncool enough to deserve respect in this place.

Firstly, it's around 6 or so on a Friday. My girl and I go to meet a friend at this...place. Weird vibe as soon as we walked in this place. Yes it is a dive bar, but you'd expect some friendliness or playful banter from the bartender. No. Even getting the opportunity to order a drink was like pulling teeth.

So, I order a beer (I drink everything for the record) for myself, and my girl is a little picky and requested an Absolut and cran. No big deal. Well, the bartender decides to offer the well vodka, which according to him was basically the same. She makes the gross face and denies the substitution. True as it may have been, she gets what she wants, she's a CUSTOMER, she's not running for congress. He rudely serves the drinks and says to us: "Next time a bartender offers advice like that, you should take it, because they know a lot more than you do".

Whoa, whoa, whoa bro. Just because you have your little power trip at a shitty...SHITTY bar in the Haight, doesn't mean you have the right to give me or anyone stern admonitions about our alcohol choices. People want what they want. Maybe you have to go home at night to your cold, empty, unfurnished studio and cry yourself to sleep, but you don't have to bring the attitude when you talk to me. Get a hobby, man. Additionally, I know plenty about alcohol...probably more than I should. Well liquor is not an intellectual pursuit of mine, so save it for someone who cares.
author: Berg W.

description: Stopped here for an early beer en route to Golden Gate Park for Outside Lands. It's a true dive bar, full of interesting characters and artifacts.
author: Kelly B.

description: Outstanding time no thanks to Lily w/ her jokes.
author: Edwin M.

description:
This is a cool bar for wanna-be's, poseurs, & trendy hipsters.

They used to have a great juke box, but now it sucks ass.  

They get two stars because it USED TO BE a very cool hang out.
author: Larry A.

description:
After getting our high-brow scotch up the block at Alembic, my companion and I decided to low-brow it before calling the night a night. The tender of our portion of the bar was Nick, or so I've put together. He and his finely coiffed hair bounced around from one patron to another like a drunken... well, like a drunken bartender, which was exactly was he was.

"What're you drinking tonight?" he enthusiastically inquired when he landed in front of us. I don't remember whether we asked for whiskey or he did, but my beautiful companion asked what whiskey he recommended. "Powers."

"Two shots of that, then!" we respond as one slurred voice.

"Oh, crap, now I'm going to have to do a shot with you!" he half-muttered, half-exclaimed as he retrieved the bottle.

After slamming a shot with us, he proceeded to make a chilled tequila shot for another patron. First try: he poured a straight tequila shot, and was corrected. On the second try, he was a little more mindful. Shaker-- check. Ice-- check. Ice in shaker-- check. Shake, then pour into shot glass... and out comes a few dribbles of water. No tequila. "That's it, I'm done! I'm drunk!" he exclaimed, and handed over the shaker and tequila bottle to another tender before wandering away.

This makes Nick the best bartender... EVER. And I will cut anyone who says otherwise. With a spoon.

Someday, I'm going to have to make it all the way over to the pool tables, the jukebox, and perhaps even a second round at the restroom.
author: Paul B.

description: It's there. Usually old men. Ehh... group thing not solo thing
author: Lisa S.

description:
One star for the POS ginger bartender at Murio's that wouldn't let my brother from New Zealand buy a drink because the birth date on his New Zealand license was 'backwards'.  Here's some advice, do some traveling so that you can figure out that America is not the only country on the planet.  

ps he is also the same bartender that told me a month ago that San Francisco bars would no longer accept passports as proof of identification/age.  Um... you can travel the world with a passport but you cannot buy a drink?  makes total sense.   Too bad he ruins the whole vibe of a potentially awesome bar.

pss Here's to the woman bartender earlier in the day who accepted his ID.  She's obviously an educated and reasonable person.
author: Kate H.

description: Unless you're of Anglo-Saxon descent, I would not recommend this joint to anyone else. Yes, it is very shishi, and service is way below standards. If you are anything less you will be met with a condescending bartender, unless you're of Anglo-Saxon descent.
author: Adrienne B.

description: When I visit SF I always have to stop for "a" drink at Murio's. I say "a" because I usually end up staying much longer then I should. Great drinks, very cool bartenders and some very fun locals.  This please is awesome.   I wil continue to visit when back in town.  cheers!
author: B I.

description:
Murios is a filthy, seedy dive bar. I'm having trouble coming up with much else to tell you about it. 

Tall boys of PBR are available, opened and ventilated with an awl for you. I'm not sure I'm brave enough to have a mixed drink here.
author: matthew r.

description:
This is a great place to hang out at and meet everyone you know who has hit rock bottom.

Ok, not quite rock bottom, but close.  If you have a job selling weed in front of McDonald's, this is the place to come to after you've sold your last gram.
author: Tim G.

description:
The jukebox alone gets this bar five stars.
Kind of pockets of atmospheres here.
One end of the bar feels totally dif from the other, ya know?
It's a cool place when not overrun. 
Good bang for your buck on the mixers as well.
author: Theo R.

description: One of the only bars in town with Radeberger beer ONTAP-that gets 5 stars in my book. Great Jukebox cool peeps too.
author: Ann H.

description:
On our Red Vic trip Friday night, the pre-show entertainment options consisted of tapas and fine bourbon (c/o Cha Cha Cha & The Alembic), or pizza and PBR (c/o Escape from New York & Murio's).  

We went with pizza and PBR, partly because they didn't involve waiting, but mostly because that's just the way we roll (but really because they didn't involve waiting).

I didn't really find this place to be as filthy as the other reviews make it out (with the exception of the bathroom, but that's kind of a given in a place like this).  Random J and I saddled up with a couple of tallboys (which was my first ever PBR in a bar, now that I think about it) and hit the pool table (also a first for a bar--these things are usually taken over by people far better and surlier than myself).  After a couple minor obstacles (#1: trying to get the damn quarters to go in--you gotta put your back into it) (#2:  humbly asking the lady at the other pool table where I could find the ball rack (hint: it's inside the table)) we were good to go.  I was winning until I sunk the 8-ball into the wrong pocket.  With a few quarters left, we tried our hand at Ms Pac-Man and Galaga and, unsurprisingly, sucked.  Man, the buttons on that machine have seen better days.

Total Cost: 2 $4 tallboys + $0.75 pool game + $0.50 of arcade games =  $9.25.  That's some damn cheap entertainment for two people in SF.

Another bonus: This place plays some great tunes.  Marshall Tucker Band's "Can't You See" was a particular highlight.
author: Wes M.

description:
Ended up here after Bay to Breakers to continue the drinking that had started at 8AM that morning. 

Overall cheap drinks, tall boy Pabst ($3), and a pool table in the back made it a nice place to chill and recap the hilarity of the day. 

The decor is typical dive bar and showing its age so don't expect anything fancy. It actually reminds me of pubs in the Mile End section of London (gritty and with a hardcore regular crowd). 

The place was crowded on Sunday but I have a feeling that its a lot less lively the rest of the year.
author: Arin N.

description:
Grabbed an afternoon drink here with a friend. There were enough people inside to make us not feel alcoholic. I haven't been here at night and don't know what the nightlife is like... But yea, good daytime vibe.

I mean, it's def a dive. But if you're okay with that... Cool place.
author: jared c.

description:
What a cool dive bar!
The jukebox is crazy!!
I had to check twice to make sure I hadn't stepped through a transdimentional rift and ended up in front of Zeitgeist's jukebox...  Is there some kind of rule about reviewing while drunk at 3:08 in the morning?

The drinks *are* strong, BTW.

After hanging out with friends I hadn't seen in years, buying a couple of rounds, and being basically drunk and queing up a ton of music I never got the chance to hear I decided to go next door and browse their, uh, glasswares...  I'll save that one for when I'm sober enough to remember the name of the place.  After an interesting brief shopping trip (so to speak) it's off to... the Lucky Penny!
author: Theron L.

description:
GG Bridge Iron Workers.  Hipsters.  Raging alcoholics that smell like sausage.  What more could you ask for in a bar?  Oh, wait, combine that with a piss-soaked bathroom and 24 oz cans of PBR and you've got Murios!
Murio's was my first "local" upon moving to SF and ever since then i've always had a deeply embedded love for it.  I never fit in with anybody else who drank here, I never met anybody here, and certainly there are better bars....yet I kept going day after day.  If you go expecting ANYTHING, you'll be disappointed.  Go with a working liver, a few bucks, no expectations and Murio's will be there for you all night long.
author: Zev K.

description: As an ex-murion I approached the new bar with skepticism but it was great!  Nothing like Murio's but still a really nice,  comfortable bar.  The bartender was great. The booze was just as I remembered it...the only thing that sucked was that the music was totally lame. I couldn't handle it for more than 20 mins
author: Robert S.

description:
A friend of mine said we were going to a bar in the Haight, not having usually gone for drinks in the Haight, I wasn't sure what to expect but Murio's was not what I was expecting, that's for sure.

The trophy room is a solid dive bar that would fit in anywhere in the city. Very much your typical pool table, juke box, wood bar, cheap drink type of place. Lots of room for big groups in the back and plenty of seat-age. Put Livin' on a Prayer on the Juke box and get ready to get a crowd singing.

It's the kind of bar you want to hit up on your way home from work and just relax at until all those loud kids show up and you start yelling at them to get off your lawn. 

It's worth coming in and looking at all the ceiling art. It's wallpapered in caricatures of either patrons or employees of times past. I guess I should have asked. 

Come in, have a drink or four, pet some folks' dogs and make a night of it.
author: Andy A.

description:
An old friend of mine was proposed to on the bar of this bar. He got right up on the bar and popped that question.

We decided to have her bridal shower there, and the bartender was so cool he let the entire group of us (about 12 drunken women) get up on the bar to re-enact the moment.

I've had a lot of fun wild times here. Its a dive. Not all dive bars are a good thing, but this one is ok by me.

The bartenders even have the right amount of cranky going on.
author: Marz W.

description:
Murio's, Alembic and Citrus club in the upper haight are part of what I call my "bermuda triangle."  Because I am a lady of convenience, I never venture outside of the three block radius from my house.  When I have friends visiting from out of town, they get this grand tour of my neighborhood and no one seems to complain.  

Murio's is extremely dark and cold.  But they have pinball and pool tables.  The environment is not really conducive to friendly conversation among strangers, but I haven't met any jerks there.  Sometimes creepy people hang out there. Once I was there with an ex boyfriend of mine and this guy kept saying what a good looking couple we were.  Somehow the conversation basically ended with him suggesting that we all have a threesome.  Oh. I forgot to mention he had long hair and was wearing a cape, so needless to say I had to decline his generous offer.  Good times.
author: Jade L.

description:
When myself and my Wife visited the greatest city on earth back in 08,and my Wife being a big Joplin/late 60's fan we spent the day in the Haight district (I was in S.F for the rich history of Bay Area Thrash,but that's another story). So we were having a great time wandering the streets,had a look at what my Wife thought was Joplins old house, bought a couple of t-shirts had a bite to eat looked in a few shops,you know the thing.....As we were reaching the bottom end of Haight St we decided that a drink was in order.As luck would have it this decision occured just as we were passing by The Trophy Room.Now from the outside the place didn't look too much,but this isn't meant to put the place down,in my world not looking much is a good thing,i'm a Metalhead, if my feet don't stick to the floor I feel uncomfortable (My feet didn't stick to the floor here so don't worry!!) Once inside one look behind the bar told me that this was the right place to pop in...when you are in a different country (even one that speaks the same language as you) it can sometimes be a little bit daunting to just walk into somewhere especially a Dive Bar several thousand miles away from home. But not here,straight to the bar, 2 bourbon and cokes and away we go!!....After a while we got chatting (accosted) by a guy called Raymond who was from Boston (if he still hangs there there say hi from me). Who likes to take the pee out of us tea drinkers : ) Now, by means of witchcraft Raymond managed to talk us into supplying him with a couple of Long Island Iced Teas (without the Gin). This is when things took a turn for the odd/weird/Haight District...*disclaimer* Lee"Bio-Zombi"Z in no way endorses being in Rome and doing what the Romans do!!..My wife and Raymond got to talking about herbal cigarettes. And in no time at all a trip to Hippie Hill in Golden Gate Park had been organized and certain medicinal items were procured and enjoyed......In the 2 weeks that we spent in San Francisco we enjoyed 3 really good drinky sessions, one in Whisky Thieves,one in North Beach who's name escapes us. But by far the most memorable was spent in the company of Raymond and the lovely people of The Trophy Room.
 We will be back next year,please don't let it have changed!!!!!
author: Lee Z.

description:
If you're a champ you should hang out at Murio's Trophy Room.

Of course you'll probably end up drinking like a champ and feeling far from that the next day.

One main reason; drinks here are cheap.  The PBR Tallboys are like $4 or something and always served COLD.  Even if the novelty of drinking tallboys in a bar has worn off for you, pints of their delicious tap beer (including one of my personal favorites Red Tail Ale) come in at about $3.50.  And yes, they have a full selection of booze for all you non-beer drinkers.  

Yeah the layout is a little weird; if you get stuck in that middle "bridge" sort of area you'll definitely be getting jostled but so far it hasn't been hard to find a decent space on either side of the place.  

The jukebox has a good selection of punk rock and rock n' roll, which I know seems a little "typical" for SF dives, but personally, I'll take that any day.  The one thing I could stand to have at this joint is an ATM (or at least take card, dammit) but given that it's low key, mostly mellow and a good place to throw back some drinks make me shut up.

Now if only I could get my caricature on the ceiling....
author: Steven R.

description:
This place is FANTASTIC!!  

The bartender was friendly and nice, the drinks were delicious and cheap, and the jukebox was one of the best I've seen in the city, It was a really great way to spend an evening!! 

I would certainly recommend this place to anyone looking for a great, simple, no-nonsense bar in SF!!
author: Ignatious M.

description:
A pretty fun place. Maybe a little too bright, and certainly more annoying as the night wears on and people spill out of the several sports bars and music clubs nearby, but still fun.

We've had incredible luck with the bartenders at Murio's. Without a doubt some of the friendliest in the city. Combine that with quick and no-nonsense drink pouring and you've got a great spot for the early evening before it gets too jam packed. Again, if I were running the place, I'd take out about half of the lighting as it seems to constantly have a '2 AM, everybody out' kind of feel where you're squinting against a harsh floodlight just to see if you're name's come up on the pool table yet. It also could benefit from some darker carpet or a fresh coat of paint that isn't a primary color. Bright and happy might be good for an IKEA, but it's crap for bars.

All in all however, we'd still recommend giving Murio's a try. After all, how impressive is it that the staff here are able to stay this friendly and cordial when most of the people walking by are stoned tourists? 

Never mind.
author: Andrew L.

description:
49ers QB Joe Montana was a closet bisexual who used to go to all-night coke parties in the Castro. Any given Saturday, he'd be up all night, getting him some dick, getting him some yay -- the night before a game. 49ers management had a special phone number they'd call when Joe was MIA: the SFPD, who would then go into the Castro, find him and bring him home in time for a few hours' sleep.

The reason why Joe was so well-known for second-half comebacks? It'd take him that long to sober up, clear his head, and remember how to play football.

This is only one of the better stories I've heard at John Murio's Trophy Room, named for the Hawaiian tennis great. 

Will there ever be a bar called The Breakfast Nook in Chris R.'s Starter Home ? I doubt it, which is why John Murio is great and we are not.
author: Chris R.

description:
Nothing like going to Murio's to have a drink after a hot, stressful day, play a game of pool or have a drink with your friends and buddies. It's a dive bar alright, so dont expect your fancy, girly drinks here, just the good ol' beer, whiskey and Vodka acompanied by a jukebox full of classic tunes of rock. 
The patrons are always friendly, and many of them you can see everyday, being part of the peculiar bar culture of Murio's for more than 30 years. 
The bartenders are just fantastic, providing good conversation, jokes and drinks. Ask for Nick when you go there
author: Elvin R.

description: The Jukebox is my hero. I like everyone who hates this place. People are funny. Just drink your drink and listen to the jams.
author: Christa A.

description:
I love this place when it's empty on a weeknight.  That's when you can really tell how dirrrty it is.  The highlights are strong drinks, a couple of pool tables that people aren't fighting over, and the bartender who is also the bouncer.

All bets are off on the weekends though when you deal with all the spill over from Cha Cha Cha.  I fear those people.
author: Susan S.

description: Back in the day it was nice not to be thrown out because you and your friends are "STRANGE" and getting stranger by the minute!!
author: Kevin B.

description:
What can I say? The cliché music, the coked-out homeless guitar player, the shamelessness that automatically overtakes your body upon entrance and drives you to request $1 miller high lifes and do the robot all night...

Murio, you done me good.
author: Talk N.

description:
Excellent. Cheap beer. Good atmosphere. Awesome bartenders.

We came in for the last stop of our Haight bar crawl on a Saturday night and f-g loved the place. 

The bartender was foul-mouthed and funny and we talked s-t all night long. 

Canned beers were as cheap as $2 each and Pliny the Elder was on tap for $4 a glass. IPA lovers will also find Racer 5 and Brew Free or Die on tap. 

Definitely recommended.
author: Michael M.

description:
Good service, great music, not too crowded on a Saturday night. 
Waiting for a table at Cha Cha Cha's wasn't nearly as unbearable with this gem right down the way. The host even offered to go to Murio's to tell us our table was ready. Stellar!
Love the art on the ceiling.
author: Amy J.

description:
Lots of guys in here.  When I walked up to order my drink I felt like I was on stage, every head turned and eyes followed my every move.  A little creepy.  Also, oddly enough...the bartender never looked my way.  Took me a long time to get his attention, I think it wasn't until my tall friend came up wondering what was taking so long that the bartender finally came over.

There is a pool table that seems to be always busy.  Don't remember hearing any tunes but I'm sure there is music being played somewhere.  The layout of the place is nice.  Lots of bar seating along the walls.  Not really my kind of place.  Although I'm sure if I lived closer it would be another star, it wasn't too busy and probably under normal circumstances it's easy to get a quick drink here.
author: Mary R.

description: The best bar in the Haight, and one of the best bars in SF. Nick is the coolest bartender in the city and the selection of beers can't be beat (lots of local/NorCal stuff like Russian River without even being aggressively advertised). Also CHEAP. Go!
author: Ryan K.

description:
I love this place. It's messy, it's divey, the drinks are cheap, the characters strong and the wall decor definitley keeps you occupied. The jukebox is good, the bathrooms are not.
The bartenders are friendly, and the occassional pirate may show up. 
If you're afraid of Haight Street or getting your fingernails a little dirty, this bar probably isn't for you, but I love the pool tables, the uncertainity of who or what will walk in and the cheap booze.
Hurray for Murio's!
author: Jessica P.

description: Stop #1 in our day-drinking-in-Haight adventure. Strong pours, nice staff, friendly patrons. Surprisingly clean bathroom. I'd drink here again.
author: Lyn P.

description:
I used to come in here back in the day when the Amobea record store used to be the Park Bowl. My grandfather and Uncle would frequent this spot as well as the Gold Cane and Paul malls all on Haight.

You would wait until they were drinking and playing pool with their friends then my cousin and I would hit them up for money for bowling and video games. When they had some drinks and were in a good mood we could get money from them and sometimes the friends as well.

These days it's not the same but I hit it up once in awhile and it always seems to be hit or miss..I have had some okay drink nights in here
author: Kim R.

description:
Of all of the bars on Haight Street I think this is my favorite.  The bar is long so there is plenty of room to pull up a stool for a long evning of booze.

The jukebox has tons of cool tunes.  I am actually giving this place an extra star because the have 'Broken Hearts, Empty Bottles', one of my favorite drinking records... ever.

Yes, there are drunks and drug addicts.  Better than the striped shirts sucking down some sweet rum drink at Hobson's.

Enjoy.
author: Thadd L.

description: I miss the old murios!!!! went here after they remodeled and it's awful! nothing at all like my favorite old dark dive filled with awesome locals and they took pliny off tap! I can forever complain about the change, one thing I do like is the comfy couches in the back but I'd take the old dingy cave like back area any day. No place to dance :( Nick is the only reason I'd ever return.
author: ariana m.

description:
the haight. i hate it. the only reason to be there during the day is for some pressing issue. once you tattooo your face and use stolen dogs for heat, youve given up on life.....anyway. i always stop at murios on the way home. 2$ pbr. good juke box.

all they need is a darts area.
author: aidan m.

description:
Good ol' Murio's is a place largely unaffected by the many changes around it. Over the years, just about every storefront on that side of the block has morphed from one establishment to another, yet Murio's endures. The interior is a bit larger than the old days (the result of a unused room being converted into space to put another pool table, I believe), but nonetheless, it's pretty much the same. Sometimes, a constant in a sea of change is a good thing. 

Besides, that, there's a good crew of bartenders and a fairly decent jukebox. Drinks are still pretty cheap too. I like to drop in on a weekday afternoon and see my buddy Waterfall (he opens the Haight St. Fair every year with a blast from his mighty conch shell), who almost always has a new edition of his poetry 'zine, The Waterfallian, ready to give me. His stuff revolves around anti-war and political themes, and is probably the only poetry I'll read for sheer enjoyment. I usually like to grab a taco or two from Balazo down the street, hang out and chat with Waterfall about politics (or shoot the breeze with friends/aquaintances who pop in from time to time), and catch a ballgame on ESPN or whatever is on, before retreating back to my home base.

I do miss the old Nightbreak days, when there was an actual live music venue next door, but oh well...
author: ACE A.

description: Murio's is a great place to have a shot of Fernet, rock out to a sweet juke box, or play a game of pool. My favorite time going there is always after a kickball game. It's a great place to have a beer and a piece of pizza. Drink prices are right on point, and there's always a spot at the bar. It's an oldie but goody you must stop by and experience. Say hi to Nikki and Marge. There kick ass bartenders that you should know!
author: monika l.

description:
Floors - disgusting 
Chairs - disgusting 
Bathroom - beyond disgusting


 Taking in all the disgusting aspects at Murio's, there doesn't seem to be much of a reason to go. But it more than makes up for it by having friendly bartenders who aren't too cool to look down upon you. They not only serve tall-boys of Pabst Blue Ribbon, but they'll even puncture it with an awl for increased airflow and more rapid consumption.


 And the né plus ultra of the Trophy Room? Proximity to Amoeba. As if I need my inhibitions reduced before going into record buying Valhalla.
author: Omid T.

description: watched the suns sweep the spurs here last sunday, they have toshiba HDTVs and when the jukebox isn't playing, depending on the bartender, you might hear the cure's pornography album playing.  VIVA LOS SUNS!!!
author: Pickle R.

description:
When I'm in the mood for a killer bloody mary, I head to Murio's.  It's like a meal in itself loaded with picked asparagus, green beans, celery, and peppers.  Extra spicy for me, thank you very much!  

Be sure to check out the art on the ceiling while you're there!
author: Jessica H.

description:
4 stars for the people, the grunge and the pabst.

That one extra star for the Lenin poster behind the bar.

I followed  a gang of pirates here one night for chrissakes!

That's an extra star the site won't let me give Murio's.
author: Jen I.

description:
This is actually one of my favorite bars in SF.  I'm normally there during the daytime(recovering from the night before) so keep that in mind.  Great jukebox selection, great bartenders, right next door to Amoeba, pool tables, relaxed atmosphere and my wife swears they make the best bloody mary she's ever had.

If there is any downside I would say that parking is difficult in that area, but that's not the bar's fault.
author: Vince G.

description:
Always a solid choice!

Drinks are reasonably priced and the jukebox is packed with great albums. It's also one of those rare places where the music is not too loud to hold a regular conversation.

The bartenders are fun to chat with and they make sure your glass never goes empty.
author: Jill M.

description:
I love this place, and I wish to hell I knew about it in the years I lived in the City.  A few years ago on a visit, I was trying to work off a hangover and trying to work up the energy to do my usual 2-3 hour CD/DVD binge at Amoeba Records next door.  Caffeine, food, lots of water, and a trip to the beach still didn't sooth my aching regretful soul.  So time for a small hair of the dog to smooth things out, as it were.

Six blissful hours later, I decided to save Amoeba for another day.  2-3 kick ass spicy bloody mary pints, several Red Hook pints, and a few Jameson's shots took care of any shopping plans I may have had, and I felt a hell of a lot better.  I wasn't even broke.  It's one of the cheapest bars in San Francisco, and utterly without pretension.  It was the Thursday before St. Patrick's Day weekend, and I watched at least 7 groups or pairs of obviously underage people try to get a drink there.  Being right where Haight Street hits Golden Gate Park, there's a fair amount of runoff as far as the tourist trade goes.  I must say, short of booting them to the street, the bartender did the most efficient, amusing, and occasionally polite job of getting rid of the teen drinkers.  It's been years so I forgot the name and the face, but the bartender was a cool guy that had been employed at one point doing repairs on the Golden Gate Bridge, had moved up to the Pacific Northwest somewhere, and had just moved back to SF a few weeks before my entrance into his dark, divey part of heaven.  Let's put it this way, the bar was fairly dead since I was doing some early drinking (walked in around 10-10:30) and this guy was a genuinely interesting person to talk to.  He even got me into watching the NasCar race on TV, and I freaking hate NasCar.  Loathe it.  Racing to me is the most boring sport on the planet.  This guy had enough facts, trivia, and stories about races he had either gone to or watched, that his commentary actually made watching the monotonous race interesting.  And again, totally nonpretentious.  Non-hipster, non-scenester, and just down to earth.  Kind of like a neighborhood redneck-ish dive transplanted somehow into the Upper Haight.  

I avoided the Upper Haight for the most part when I lived in SF, mainly due to the abundance of hippies and dreadful (no pun intended) pseudo-hippies/trust fund wannabe people.  Murrio's is as non-hippie you can get for the Upper Haight, in fact there's lots of good punk represented on the jukebox, including the fairly obscure early 70's punk band Radio Birdman.  

Most people who I've met here were really cool.  On another daytime visit I had programmed a Poison Idea song and a Hard-Ons song on the jukebox, and was working on my pint.  A punk lookin guy and his girlfriend (?) walked in and sat a couple seats down from me.  When the Hard-Ons song started (I think it was "Girl in the Sweater") the guy said, "Alright, the Hard-Ons!" and started bobbing his head to the music.  Once my Poison Idea song started "Just to Get Away" the guy looked straight at me: "Did you play this?!  This song RULES!"  Needless to say we talked for awhile.  I know this has nothing to do with the bar itself, the beer, or the prices, but 50% of a bar's appeal IMO is the crowd that hangs out there, and Murrio's is fairly douchebag-free due to its lack of pretension. This guy's girlfriend was wearing a Texas Chainsaw Massacre 2 pin, so that maybe gives you an idea of "my crowd" or whatever.

The Haight Street tourism/crazy person spillover does occasionally result in some lameness, but sometimes to amusing results.  My favorite was the Jim Morrison wannabe-looking guy with the snakeskin cowboy hat, who seemed like he had sampled a fair amount of 60's style psychedelia, if you catch my drift.  Literally the second I'm thinking to myself, "Does this guy wanna be Ian Astbury from the Cult?" he TAKES OFF HIS SHIRT FOR NO REASON, muttering dopey poetry-like nonsense, and CHANGES INTO A CULT T-SHIRT AT THE BAR.  At this point, I'm thinking, is this Ian Astbury himself fallen onto hard times? Or is this guy in some (God forbid) Cult tribute band?  Either way it was a fuckin surreal mindbending moment that could probably happen only at Murrio's.

Anyway, the point of this rambling review is that Murrio's is a reasonably priced, fairly pretension-free place if you want to go have a few beers in a non-meat market type environment.  For major drinking and occasional socializing.
author: The D.

description:
I was out and about with my friends friends looking for a cool little spot to hang out and have a couple of drinks and listen to some music.  We seemed to be going into the direction of the Haight.  So we thought why not go to MILK.  As we got there the door man told us it was a $10 cover charge.  It was already 12:30am and we didn't feel like spending money on a cover charge, so we opted to head over to the bar across the street to get some drinks.  

And so we encountered Murio's.  A great little neighborhood dive bar filled with regulars in the back area enjoying beer and playing pool.  As my friends and I sat at the bar perusing at the liquor selections that they had to choose from, we met a kind fellow who wanted to make some friends that night.  He talked to us about how Murio's is his favorite bar, he played matchmaker earlier that evening for some strangers and proceeded to serenade us with some Otis Redding tunes.  Mind you that he was already a bit tipsy, as this bar was not his first stop for the night, but he proved to be very entertaining.  The bartender and the regulars were nice and chatty, which made a close to our evening quite enjoyable.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
I find it hilarious that I am going to give this place 4 stars. This place screams sketchtastic from the moment you walk in the door underneath the glowing red neon sign and notice that those really are plastic christmas lights on the ceiling.

I have a hilarious story about how my rum and coke came in one of those tiny bathroom solo cups. Granted, I still got a very nice pour from the bartender, but it was hysterical at the lack of coke that went into the plastic bathroom solo cup. What made this whole thing funnier? When I wanted another, the bartender needed my solo bathroom cup back. Yes. That extra $0.005 cents was totally going to break this place for profit. At the same time, this was so over the top weird that I couldn't help but thinking it was hilarious, not bastardy. 

So like I said, I don't know why this place gets 4 stars, but it feels like 4 stars. Its one of those places that screams "get really really tanked here, and then go puke on the McDonald's drive thru speaker". You just gotta have at least one of those bars, yeah? We went here prior to a roller derby match. I can't say there is a better match for a pre-roller derby drink fest. If you don't go here in an equally sappy/raucous mood, I doubt you'll have a good time
author: Sean C.

description: This is a great Rock N' Roll dive...first off, The Rolling Stones were playing on the Juke Box, which had a pretty good selection. Second cheap drinks including $1 PBR cans sunday nights and $1 Miller high life monday nights. Last but not least, I was regailed with stories of Keith Moon and Joe Strummer by an elderly british man. Epic win!
author: Camille A.

description:
after getting denied for a job, i hopped on the muni to haight for some good ol' retail therapy, bought some books and ducked into murio's on my way to amoeba....i never made it to amoeba.

i knew i found my bar when a random guy tried to use the bathroom without buying a ($2) beer and the bartender got all sass-attack on his ass. i'll admit, i had an instant girl crush on the bartender. she was witty and adorable, doesn't take any shit and could probably kick anybody's ass. she also gave the best "cut off" speech i've ever heard. it's a delicate process telling someone they've had enough..  kudos to you, marjorie (hope i got the spelling right.. heck, hope i got the name right.)!
author: darcy a.

description:
in the 90's the trophy room used to be my favorite bar.  now, it sucks.  i went in there two months ago while my girl friend was shopping at whole foods.  i'm not there two minutes and a fight breaks out.  i watch it for a while until a large black man walked in and broke up the fight.  the female bartender was useless.  she was wasted! really wasted behind the bar and didn't even try to stop the men.  here is where i say i have actually done door/bounced in my time.  when a fight breaks out you toss both people out.  fuck them, they can fight on the street for all i care.  however, the drunk wasted bartender let the guy she knew stay in and continue drinking.  frankly, if you are getting in to fights at bars, you might consider not drinking for the rest of the day.  it's just a thought.  after all this BS i left.

flash forward to a few weeks ago... i was in the trophy room again.  there is another wasted female bartender bartending.  i'm not there two minutes when some homeless guys pit bull bites a woman in the hand.  hey dumb ass bartenders, you don't serve homeless people in the bar!  you also don't allow their fuckin pit bulls in there either.  i hope the troyphy room got sued over this!  fuck this place now.  it used to be great but has gone down hill.  oh yeah.. what's with the stupid turn table in back.  how loser wanna be hip can you get trophy room?

the trophy room shouldn't even get a star.
author: T D.

description:
Murio's Trophy Room. At 5 pm on a Saturday night it served as suitable place to meet a date and drink some whiskey. 

People call this place a dive, but it's a very mild dive. It's too bright and too clean to be a proper dive. They have good beer on tap for 3-4 bucks a pint. A great place to start an evening in the haight, not crowded or loud. 

They have a jukebox. Maybe 50% is cool, Pixies, Two Gallants FTW. Two bucks equals 8 plays are you serious?

There was an old dude and his little dog and they were playing fetch and the dude was making out with the dog.
author: Jim C.

description: Yep, it's a dive. But a nice one, and convenient to Amoeba... $3 happy hour! Pool tables! Cheetos! (no, not for free)
author: Maximillian M.

description: GREATEST BAR IVE EVER BEEN TO!  Shot out to Mr Cortez the bartender.  This place was great!  Dim lights, loud music and strong drinks!  Not to mention the bartender was CRAZY funny.  We came from Cha Cha Cha's to get some "real" drinks.  I live in the east bay but id definitely head back there for a good time.  The ppl in the bar looked scary but were down to earth...and thats my kind of place:-)
author: Randi C.

description: First time visit, we stopped by say hi to some friends. Xmas lights on the ceiling! People are extremely friendly. Bartender is very nice and hyper! Ordered sex on the beach when I got in. He made fun of me about there are some sand on my butt pretty much the whole time we were there. lol My bad, it wasn't the drink for a dive bar. Anyway, happy folks are here. Music is very 90s but in good way. Only 3 stars because the bathroom front door (more like a half cover) is facing to DJ stage. Everyone is able to see when u fixing your hair. Ugh... (Thanks god it's not the toilet door...)
author: Flora F.

description: Check out the old school photos at the back of the bar. This must've been a hot diggity dawg of a place back in the day.
author: Aim E.

description: If ya want a cheap drink at a no-nonsense place, where you are bound to have a crazy ass conversation head to Murio's Trophy Room.  After a few drinks poured by cutie bartender Nick, everyone at Murio's Trophy Room is your new best friend.  But be warned: Cheap Drinks + Stumbling Distance Home = Trouble.  So 4 Stars, because every Good Girl needs a little trouble in her life.
author: Natasha R.

description: I just started hanging out in upper Haight, having wrongly accused it of being far too seedy for me.  Some friends took me out to Murio's, and well...I was very pleasantly surprised.  Friendly people and staff - and the booze is good and cheap!
author: Mario G.

description: I'm a big fan of dive bars, but this place blows.  Rudest bartender EVER.  Jackass wanted to charge me for a second drink to remake the drink HE poured incorrectly.  Seriously?  As an ex-bartender, I can't even fathom that kind of attitude.  I'll take my dive bar business elsewhere.
author: Vanessa N.

description:
it's a DIVE BAR, people! on haight st., for that matter... if you want to go to a sanitized pretty bar, go to the marina, you can even find these bars in the mission now-a-days... hell go across the st. to milk..whatever!
*sigh* i digress

this place is the sh!t !  nick, the bartender is cool, and i love his hat that gives him all the character!  i love the patron slim, and his dog, maganda [or was that the dog he had that passed... damn drunken nights].  spots like this bring out people of all breeds, and people who are down to earth and just want to have a damn drink.  no bull crap, no foufou decorations, no need to dress up...just give me what i come to a bar for: ALCOHOL.

despite all the 'makeovers' that haight st. has incurred, this place has stayed true to it's identity, and the realness and rawness of haight st. 

'nuff said.
author: Sheri N.

description: Does a place make you cool by name dropping it or do you bring the cool to make it worth mentioning? PBR in huge cans, classic punk rock.  Done.
author: JP Z.

description: I fucking love this bar.  Good Juke box, video games, cheap booze....   Why only four stars then?  Glad you asked...  When ever I step outside for a smoke I get accosted by holmess people and hippies.  No, I don't have any change.  No, I don't want to buy your dirt weed.  I'm not a tourist so stop trying to sell me your fake acid.  Sure, you can have a cigarrette but just one and only if you go away...  Aside from that the bar is cool.  If you shoot pool you can always get a game going and if you find yourself hungry there's good food all over Haight St.  Oh ya, if you order the 24oz PBR the bartender (without being asked) will carb the top with a knife...   you know, in case you want to pound it.
author: jason k.

description: Used to be a damn fine place to grab a beer and get harangued by greaseballs and punk rock boys before shows at the I-Beam. Also used to have trashy girls dancing on the bar in a gacked out frezny. Long gone are those days, we still pop in here for drinks after a day of shopping at Amoeba because it's  tradition. Unfortunately, now the folks seem to be having a lot less fun and the bartenders are cranky because they're being monitored at all times by an evil eye.
author: Colleen B.

description: this place is classic Haight st.   I hope with the remodeling they don't change the old skool dive bar vibe that everyone enjoys. there is enough trendy places on the street already...and i hope they keep the same kind of music and Nick is still serving us wit and cocktails...
author: SASHA B.

description: so now they have to charge $5 for beers to help pay for their 'facelift', no more tecate by the can..stopped in once for happy hour, then was told the drafts were $4...the only thing that is 'divey' about this place now is the bartenders..they should've been shipped out with the old furniture..(sorry, those arent happy hour prices) back to the gold cane for us, will give them credit for uplift because the place was terrible before, and it does still kinda have the old 'stench'...guess no amount of facelift can get odor away
author: gavin t.

description:
murio's is my neighborhood dive bar. no frills. no bull. interesting cartoons. pool tables. funky-looking regulars who no doubt have interesting stories, though i don't really need to hear them. 

i've never seen it crowded (maybe because it's usually a late afternoon or evening stop for me). interesting music on the jukebox. people will leave you alone if you want. it's simple and cheap, just what you want your neighborhood dive bar to be.
author: leslie a.

description:
dive bar, cheap drinks and pool tables.

while the service isn't the greatest, the bartender is a great guy and well worth getting into a conversation with. (everytime, it's one guy working on a friday night).

cheap drinks, kinda dirty, ton of smokers out front.
it feels like home.  *sigh*
author: Ge O.

description: Whoever wrote down that Murio's bathrooms are gross is an uptight jerk.  This is the only spot in the Haight that will let you use the bathroom to pee without buying a drink.  You can just walk right back to the left and - ah - relief!  They have a really nice big mirror in there and there's never a line.  This bar has no attitude and a nice pool table.  It's a classic spot.  It's been on the Haight for years and years and years.  A professional tennis player named Murio used to own it back in the day.
author: jane d.

description: My neighborhood watering hole. You have to appreciate Murio's for what it is--a dive bar. Always good conversation to be had there, and the bartender is beyond entertaining.
author: Mallory M.

description: i've been falling in love with this dive lately. good people, friendly prices and generous bartenders. the juke box ain't too shabby either. if you find yourself in the haight its definitely worth stopping by for a drink or five.
author: Joseph N.

description: A few years ago, a Murio's patron Yelped the now-defunct dive as being the "John Lovitz" of bars.  Crude, classless and in poor taste, both Lovitz and the old Murio's had character.  Sadly, the new iteration of this long-time Upper Haight landmark lacks any of the Lovitzness that previously drew me in.  In trying to lounge-up the place with cheap and tacky decor (square white cow hair seats and light fixtures that were seemingly a high school shop class project), the owner (who, speaking of class, has been known to dress as Adolf Hitler for fun) has simply put lipstick on a pig (or tried to shine a turd, as we say in Oklahoma).  Rather than throwing gobs of money into this renovation, he should have focused on ridding the joint of the most unsavory aspect of the bar: its lame tenders.  Nick's boorish misogyny and racism have driven off more customers than they've attracted and the relatively new female tender lacks even a modicum of charm.  That said, male patrons will be relieved that they no longer have to sneak into the women's restroom to drop a deuce, as was the case previously.  As for me, my boycott (begun when Nick demanded fellatio from a female patron as a precondition for entry a year ago) will continue and I will spend my money down the street at Alembic, where both the drinks and bartenders are thoughtful.
author: siegfried s.

description: I have been going here a lot more frequently on the weekends and I always have a good time.  Great songs on the jukebox, entertaining people to watch and plenty of beer.
author: Jenna M.

description: When I first moved here I frequented this place...frequently.  Met some crazy people and definitely consumed more than my fair share of booze and had a blast doing it.
author: Rachel N.

description: Every time I've been here they play great music and serve great drinks. Randomly I ended up meeting one of the bartenders off duty and we all went and hung out.  It's close to my house, divey, and perfect. Minus one star because a gang fight broke out in front of Milk across the street and carried into the bar and the police and ambulances ended up coming.
author: Liz O.

description: I'm the first person reviewing this place? fuuuuuck...well, considering some of the regulars in there prolly don't know the internet from their buttholes it's really not THAT big of a suprise. Wow - where do I start? I'm not as regular in there as I used to be, but Murio's still has my heart as what I would consider one of the best bars in the city. It's the best dive I've ever had the pleasure to live near and a great first date spot no doubt - there's always a nice cross section of the city in there. Lately it's been a little bit on the whiteboy side (I've been going there for maybe 5 years now?), but it's fine. Drink enough with your friends and it's like they're not even there. :) They've always got super nice folks working in there, and the jukebox is good shit. Some of the best pool players in town hang out here so make sure and bring your A game, ya herr?!
author: Justin H.

description: my old haunt...many memories of 151 and coca colas with a splash of grenadine up in this piece. good jukebox. A bartender who looked like one of the members of the HIVES used to work there. You used to be able to smoke inside...thats always fun.wicked cheap happy hour,like above and beyond the call of cheap duty.if i wasn't so morally opposed to hanging out on haight street nowadays you know I'd be at this dive in a heartbeat
author: Lauren V.

description: I actually really like this place on a weekend afternoon. It reminds me a lot of the bars in Austin and they have 24 ounce PBR cans, a jukebox, and a couple pool tables. That's really about all I need, you?
author: Cory G.

description: I will always be inexorably  linked with this bar, for being the first time I tasted the evil mistress we all know as Fernet Branca.  All I can say is that was one hell of a night....
author: Eagan I.

description: This place is way too clean and way too bright to be a dive bar. Drinks are not cheap. Single shot drinks are full of ice and not much alcohol. Double shots are stronger but the glass is pretty regular looking for $12. Service is super slow. If you are intending to get wasted on cheap drinks, this is not the place.
author: Yenly M.

description: One of the best bars ever... I stumbled in one night, was called an asshole by the bartender (Nick is the best), and then promptly made Murio' s my favorite spot in the bay. They've got Old 97's on the juke box, weird old guys in cowboy hats on any given night, and Craig (my most favorite Ameoba employee ever), I miss Murios. I miss Humboldt Hemp Ale. I miss getting drunk and fucking with the most random people on earth (hello Tom who loves Jack Daniels, Jon the vegan from NY, Fred  the guy on his way home to WA to tell his dad he's gay). This is one of the only bars I've felt comfortable drinking in alone (weird, I know).  It's perfectly acceptable for a girl to have a lonesome pint and tell people to, oh so politely, fuck off.
author: Meghan S.

description: I used to work here. What a great fucking bar. A real bar for real drunks. I just wanted to give a shout out. Great jukebox and pool players. I would like all my martinis in rocks glasses by the way.
author: Boxxxman J.

description: Have been here many times throughout the years and it is always consistently fun and entertaining. I have yet to find a more interactive group of people in any bar in SF, including the bartender(s). Always attentive and never a dull moment. Was just there last night and not only was the bartender super cool to me and my drunk friends, but the guys sitting next to us were very fun and friendly in a non pervy way. So say what you must about dive bars, but if you're up for some strong drinks, nice  folks, and great music, this is the place.
author: summer r.

description: THe greatest five bar in the city. Lots of cheap drinks, nice dark atmoshphere, killer music selection and the bartenders are badass! Ask for Nick he is the shit of all shits!
author: joshua b.

description: The best bar in the Haight, hands down.  Punk rock on the jukebox- that's all I have to say
author: Aimee J.

description: Can't escape this place. Best Dive Bar in the Haight. Pool players paradise.
author: Jessica J.

description: a good chill bar. drinks were cheap. a couple plasma's showing the warrior game. dog friendly(those 2 giant dogs were adorable). squirrel monkey's flying around(im dead serious). pool table with good players and a waiting list. interesting crowd. had never been here before dyl, but i will almost surely be back at some point.
author: Andrew T.

description: The most grim and filty den of shit  i've ever been in.  The no passport policy is a joke.  Only Americans allowed.  Is this legal.
author: Gary J.

description:
$3 well drinks during 7 hour long happy hours - lovely
being told by the bartender to not play journey with the cash he gave me for the jukebox - also lovely
the fact that there was a melvins album in the jukebox - !!!
i'm even down with the christmas lights on the ceiling.
author: Michelle S.

description:
II have begun to frequent this bar less. I am an absolute fan of dive bars and obviously because of environment. Lately, I am less than satisfied with the service of the bartenders. Militant group members have more hospitality than the bartenders at this place. As much as I like being ID'd at my age, I feel as though this task has some baring on the hostility exhibited by the employees. There was also the request to listen to a recent sports game, that, as the bartender explained, would cause difficulty for him monitoring the dozen patrons (who were also watching the game) and so proceeded to put music on the jukebox. Before this incident, I paid for a mixed drink that had too much tonic and no alcohol and asked to have it strengthened. The bartender responded rudely to this and stated that he couldn't add more to the drink, but would have to make a new one, much to his chagrin. Now, as much as I appreciate a new drink, I do not feel like wasting a drink that would have been perfectly acceptable on it's own. 

The list of frustrations continue with this spot; most including the service. I don't expect a red-carpet treatment and have certainly experienced my fair share of rude servers, but it appears that the prerequisite at Murios is to treat all patrons with discontent and hostility.
author: Sarah M.

description: never had a drink here but I was walking down Haight street one day needing to use the restroom in the worst way so I hurried into this bar...used the bathroom, flushed, washed my hands and headed towards the exit...I heard the bartender say something to me so I looked over... he saw the confused look on my face and repeated "what can I get you?"  To which I replied, "oh nothing I just had to use your bathroom" THEN he said in a really really pissed off manner "Can't you fucking read man, the bathroom is for fucking customers ONLY!"  ... I had nothing to say back, since I was in shock and I'm the one with something lose so I kept walking, thinking "dam that is one fucked up bartender.
author: Adrian H.

description: you know, I really try to be optimistic. I thought that new ownership would bring back the good ol days but like they say "lipstick on a pig"!
author: Jeff B.

description: love this place, it's like the local waterhole of san jose in san francisco that i never had. i would especially like to thank the bartender dude who spikes my hamm's can before serving it. this place has an awesome music selection (dead milkmen is a fave). one night there with my lady folk, i ordered way too many jamo's (whats new) and for some strange reason i ordered a Humboldt Hemp Ale, just to spill it all over the bar, what an ass. To my supplies, that same spike in the beer can bartender was not too mad on the outside. two thumbs up, yo!
author: Daniel M.

description: Ask the barkeep for a what is now known as a "#1".....can of Hamms and house whiskey for a finsky.....place is definitely a "Trophy Room"
author: Joe Y.

description: cheap drinks, friendly bartenders, great jukebox, good spot to play pool.  minus one star for the condition of the bathroom.
author: Daryl F.

description: absolutely my favorite bar in the city.  I moved about a year ago but continue to stop in every time im in SF.  If you have ever felt like a bartneder was too "cool for school," come here.  Nick is the most friendly and engaging drink server i have yet to encounter, and Casey can get into to some really great lengthy conversation with you.  The juke box is sweeeet!  so thanks guys cause without your great staff, you just wouldnt be you :)
author: Blanch P.
